Title: University of Sheffield HH Flexible Procurement
Description:
The ITT is issued to establish a flexible HH electricity supply agreement for the University of Sheffield. 

PLEASE NOTE: The procurement process implements the accelerated procedure as defined under regulation 2 of the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 #102 (PCR 2015).

This ITT process has followed the accelerated procedure to allow the agreement to be placed in suitable time to allow for a transfer of supplies (if required) before the start date.
The agreement needs to be in place by the start of September to allow the incoming supplier (should it be a change from the incumbent) enough time to fulfil their regulatory requirements to get the University of Sheffield's meters into their jurisdiction.
Following the standard open procedure timeline referenced in regulation 27 (2) of the PCR 2015 would not allow this to happen prior to the 1st October and the University's current agreement expires on 30th September 2017.

The contracting authority for this tender is the University of Sheffield. The tender process and resulting agreement is managed by Inenco, acting as the agent for the University. 

The agreement is three years in duration from the commencement date, with an option to extend by up to two 12 month periods beyond this. It is envisaged that the final agreement will be awarded to a maximum of one supplier.

The currently estimated levels of expenditure over the 36-month period is £18,000,000 excluding VAT.

This value is derived from high level estimates only. The client accepts no responsibility for inaccuracies in the estimates provided. This is for information only, and no guarantees are given, nor are implied as to the value of business that will be placed with successful parties participating in the resulting agreement. 

The established agreement and all associated documents are subject to any future legislation and regulatory changes applicable to the supply of utilities.

Full details of the required service can be found within the tender documents and Supporting Information section of the tender.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and the Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West,Scotland,Wales

Title: 2268/DM - Development of a Thermometry System
Description:
The Department of Civil Engineering is a world leader in the area of Blast and Ballistic effects research. Its work at the Buxton labs range from large calibre ballistics (internal and external) to full-scale blast effects. The lab provides world leading industrial and fundamental research and its research informs excellence in teaching in the area of protection systems. 

We seek to determine the evolving thermo-chemical state of the post-detonation fireball, the effect of rapid afterburn on early stage energy release, and the consequences for pressure loading. To conduct this work, we will design and fabricate a proposed Mechanisms of Blast Loading facility in which we will detonate explosive charges resulting in a 1-dimensionally propagating fireball.

Title: Funeral Services of bodies bequeathed for the purpose of anatomical education and training
Description:
The Academic Unit of Medical Education at the University of Sheffield is a leading centre for Medical Education. Our curriculum is innovative and highly regarded, developing our students to achieve their potential. The Academic Unit of Medical Education includes the Clinical Skills Centre, Medical Teaching Unit (Anatomy) and the Academic Unit of Primary Medical Care.

The University of Sheffield is one of a number of establishments which accept whole body donations after death. The majority of donors we accept are from the local area and are collected from hospitals, other funeral directors, mortuaries, care homes, nursing homes and private houses.

A donated body can be used for a number of purposes, which may include:-

1) Anatomical examination - teaching students or healthcare professionals about the structure and function of the human body

2) Education and training - training healthcare professionals on surgical techniques

The University of Sheffield wishes to award a contract for the provision of Funeral Director Services for bodies bequeathed for the purpose of anatomical education and training. 

This tender invites expressions of interest in the main aspects of the service that we wish to purchase for suitably dignified disposal of donor bodies. The required service has two essential elements:-

1)	Removal and transportation of the deceased to the successful tenderer's premises where it is stored, with onward transportation to the University of Sheffield's Medical Teaching Unit (MTU) at a later date

2)	Funerals for people who have donated their bodies to the University of Sheffield's Medical Teaching Unit (MTU)

Title: Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) machine capable of high throughput digital PCR and qPCR
Description:
The University of Sheffield is out to tender on behalf of the Department of Infection, Immunity and Cardiovascular Disease for a Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) machine capable of high throughput digital PCR and qPCR. The Florey Institute within the University of Sheffield takes an interdisciplinary approach to anti-microbial resistance (AMR) and host-pathogen interaction research. The Institute is comprised of scientists and clinicians who work closely with the Sheffield Teaching Hospital NHS Trust (STH) to deliver high-impact fundamental and translational research outputs.

We require an automated, high-throughput PCR machine to aid our gene expression studies. One of our research focuses involves measuring host gene expression changes in response to infection and this requires the measurement of large numbers of selected genes by RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) and/or real-time PCR (RT-PCR) on thousands of patient samples. In addition to this work, we also aim to use digital PCR to detect pathogens present at low copy number in patient and environmental samples.


Initially the equipment may be housed in one in the Royal Hallamshire Hospital laboratories due to the pandemic (not all University laboratories are currently open and we may need to minimise staff movement between laboratories). It would therefore be an advantage if the machine could be moved to a different location at the University at a later date. It was originally intended to be housed in the NERC Biomolecular Facility and may still move there dependent on future discussions about space.

The full technical specification can be found in the tender documentation which will be sent to you once you have expressed your interest.

Description:

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Piezoelectric Dynamometer Force Sensing Kit Purchase  on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, North West. 

Scope of Requirement
The University of Sheffield (UoS), AMRC North West wishes to invite tenders for the provision of two Piezoelectric Dynamometer Force Sensing Kits (PDFSK). The UoS have associated policies, procedures and training plans in place to ensure the safe operation and utilisation of equipment. Title: 2223/JN - Organic Rankine Cycle System
Description:
With co-funding from the European Regional Development Fund, the University of Sheffield is establishing a flagship national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) to provide a multi-technology, integrated RD and D platform, encompassing a portfolio of facilities focusing on low carbon energy generation and CCUS (Carbon Dioxide Capture Utilisation/Storage) technologies, integrated together with an overarching smart energy management system. The Centre will promote and support research, innovation and demonstration of individual and integrated technologies with the purpose of encouraging and accelerating technology development, validation and demonstration and ultimately technology commercialisation and uptake. Part of the Centre's remit is also to explore how different technologies can be combined into integrated systems in the most effective and complementary manner. 

To support and expand our R and D capability, the University of Sheffield is looking to procure a wide range of equipment focusing on bioenergy, renewable energy and CCUS technologies.

This tender is specifically focused on the procurement of an Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) System.

Title: 2306/JN - Chromatography System for Protein and Nucleic Acid Purification
Description:
The Bose Lab works on understanding the function of non-coding RNA: protein complexes, and how they regulate gene expression. The group uses a combination of functional genomics, biochemistry and structural biology to probe the mechanism of protein:RNA complexes. The lab is generously funded by a Sir Henry Dale Fellowship from the Wellcome Trust and the Royal Society. The group is also associated with a wider cross-faculty and departmental grouping of labs focused on nucleic acids research within the University of Sheffield as part of the Sheffield Institute for Nucleic Acids; the equipment will therefore be of wider interest to a number of groups within the University. 

Our work studies how non-protein coding RNAs (ncRNAs) interact with and regulate distinct activities in regulatory enzyme complexes that control chromatin accessibility and therefore transcription in mammalian systems. We have previously shown that direct interactions with ncRNAs are a key regulatory factor for these enzymes. The biochemical and structural biology experiments carried out in the group require the formation of diverse protein:nucleic acid complexes, and their subsequent purification to high levels of purity. We also incorporate a variety of fluorophores into our purified samples. As many of these complexes are only weakly associated or transient, accurate sample preparation requires the ability to operate a number of preparation protocols quickly and reproducibly. Importantly, the ability to simultaneously detect the presence of both protein and RNA components in the sample formation reaction would be beneficial to ensure complexes are formed prior to their use in downstream experiments. 

The University now requires a chromatography system to support the research into this area. 
In order to purify proteins, RNA and protein:RNA complexes, the system must be capable of a number of distinct protein purification applications, including but not limited to: Affinity chromatography (e.g Ni/Co affinity, GST, Strep-tag), Anion and cation exchange, and size exclusion chromatography. To preserve the activity and integrity of the purified samples, the system will be housed in a climate controlled cold cabinet operated at 4C. The ability to control and monitor the system remotely would be advantageous.

Title: 2241/JN - Smart Energy Management System
Description:
With co-funding from the European Regional Development Fund, the University of Sheffield is establishing a flagship national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) to provide a multi-technology, integrated RD&D platform, focusing on low carbon energy generation, hydrogen generation and utilisation through fuel cells and chemical conversion, and CCUS (Carbon Dioxide Capture Utilisation/Storage) technologies, integrated together with a smart energy management system and battery storage. The Centre will promote and support research, innovation and the demonstration of individual and integrated technologies with the purpose of encouraging and accelerating technology development, validation and demonstration and ultimately technology commercialisation and uptake. Part of the Centre's remit is also to explore how different technologies can be combined into integrated systems in the most effective and complementary manner. To establish the Centre, the University of Sheffield is looking to procure a wide range of equipment focusing on renewable energy, CCUS technologies and smart energy grid.

This tender document is specifically focused on the procurement of a system for Smart Energy Management System (SEM) for research into dynamic grid behaviour and simulation, and to assesses and optimise the operation of individual systems in a multi-element mini-grid, including the performance of CCUS elements. The SEM will be developed in two phases. In the first phase (this tender) the system will focus on monitoring and trending (and simulating) energy flows in real time, including power and heat from generating devices to consumption devices and including electrical energy storage (battery) management and grid export. It will also monitor heat flows based on heat meters from the generating devices, to thermal store, onsite cooling tower and building (and in the future to a wider site heat network). 

In the second phase, separate from this tender, the SEM will be expanded to a full site monitoring system which will also integrate data acquisition, control action for the individual converters and safety from/of individual equipment control systems providing an overall site Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition system. Whilst phase two is separate from this tender, system designs should take the expansion requirements into account in the design phase.

This is an EU open exercise. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield

Completed tenders must be returned through the same e-tendering system.

Title: 2034/JN - Continuous Extrusion Machine for Metals
Description:
The Sheffield Royce Institute is a~£34M project based in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering. Sheffield is part of the national Henry Royce Institute (with the main Hub in Manchester) which aims to grow the UK world-leading research and innovation base in advanced materials science, fundamental to all industrial sectors and the national economy. The Sheffield Royce Institute focuses on Advanced Materials Processing and will be delivered through two centres - the Royce Discovery Centre (RDC) and the Royce Translational Centre (RTC). These state of the art facilities will allow materials discovery, materials manufacturing and prototype production and will act as an open access centre of excellence for the UK. 

Proposals are invited for:

A continuous extrusion that is suitable for processing both low strength (aluminium alloys) and high strength (titanium alloys) in both powder and rod feedstock forms into fully dense products. Continuous extrusion will provide the Henry Royce Institute (HRI) a unique ability to convert oversized GA powder, used ALM powder and machining swarf into wire for a range of sectors, including wire fed ALM feedstock. The machine will be situated in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at The University of Sheffield and will be a unique, key strategic piece of equipment in the HRI. The machine will be utilized in a range of research projects ranging from novel alloy extrusion, nano-structured/ ultra-fine grained materials and metallic alloy recycling. While the machine will be housed at the University of Sheffield it will be made available to both academic and industrial partners across the whole of the United Kingdom.

Title: 2490/JS - Compact Road Sweeper
Description:
The University of Sheffield campus is considered to be a city centre campus and extends to the North and South areas of the city centre and neighbouring residential suburbs.

The Estates & Facilities Management Department (EFM) support the University in the provision, maintenance and management of the built environment and intersecting public realm spaces. This environment is managed to the highest standards of hygiene, safety & customer appeal.

Specifically, EFM work to develop and maintain the University outdoor space to the highest standard through its Landscape and Campus services teams. This includes use of mechanical sweeper equipment to maintain hygiene standards across open space, precinct & public realm areas

In May 2015 the University of Sheffield purchased a compact road sweeper plus a 5 year maintenance contract. The existing five year maintenance contract is based on the existing sweeper recording no more than 1,560 hours (averaging 30 hours per week) for each year of the contract (7,800 miles in total).

The University of Sheffield is looking to purchase a second compact road sweeper (plus a 5 year maintenance contract). The new sweeper will be deployed alongside the existing sweeper on the University's central campus and will be used for approximately 30 hours per week. There may be a slight reduction in usage outside of term time (mid-June to mid-September each year).
The purpose of this tender is to set out a specification for the following requirements:-
 
•	The purchase of one compact sweeper machine;
•	A comprehensive monthly maintenance and servicing contract (for a period of 5 years)

This sweeper will operate on a five-day week, running for up to 30 hours per week (up to 1,560 hours per annum).

The sweeper will be capable of operating in areas of high foot fall across precinct and highway spaces namely around the S10 2TN postcode.

The sweeper will operate on tarmac, bloc paved and granite setts surfaces without damaging jointing materials or drain installations.

The sweeper will be designed to remove discarded litter and leaves. It will operate in all weathers and light conditions except when temperatures fall below 4 degrees C. 

The sweeper will be equipped with a remote suction hose to enable removal of debris from areas inaccessible by the sweeper and will have a jet wash facility (in the region of 10-12L per minute at 100 bar) to allow for wash off cleaning activities.

Title: Industrial Robot (x2)
Description:
2460/474/CW/IMG/20       Industrial Robot (x2) 


The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for two industrial robots on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, IMG Group.

Scope of Requirement

The AMRC IMG Group has a requirement for two kinematically-linked medium payload, six-axis robots for use in creating a research cell dedicated to the automated winding of coils for electrical machines to be installed at the AMRC Factory 2050 facility in Sheffield.
As this cell will be used as a research platform, it must offer a means of controlling the robots in real-time via an external PC with non-proprietary software, e.g. ROS-Industrial. To ensure best value for money, the AMRC are willing to consider and review a proposal for ex-demo robots, which meets all technical, commissioning and warranty items specified.

Title: 2336/LM - Named Veterinary Surgeon (NVS) Services
Description:
The University of Sheffield wishes to appoint a provider of Named Veterinary Surgeon services:
•	To carry out the responsibilities of the Named Veterinary Surgeon as laid down in the Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986 (ASPA 1986) and in accordance with the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeon's Code of Practice for Named Veterinary Surgeons, including the provision of expert veterinary knowledge and  advice on the use, husbandry and welfare of animals. 
•	Provision of veterinary advice and services as required (which may be over 24 hours a day, 7 days a week and 365 days a year) on site at the University of Sheffield as necessary.
•	To carry out site visits as required and typically every week for up to 12 hours.
•	Work collaboratively with, and advise the Establishment Licence Holder, the Director of Biological Services and the various NACWOs, providing information and reports when appropriate.  
•	Advise on research and husbandry procedures and the impact of disease, with the aim of continually refining and improving procedures and minimising animal suffering.
•	Familiarisation with all procedures being carried out under a project licence.
•	Provide training and advice in appropriate procedures to staff and users of the animal facility. This would include surgical techniques and knowledge of how to assess animals for potential side effects or distress.
•	Advise on the humane end point for animals deemed to be suffering unnecessarily to the Personal/Project licence holder.
•	Provide advice on the health status of animals; maintain health records and monitor trends where required. 
•	Advise on biosecurity and appropriate quarantine arrangements.
•	Prescribe and direct the use of prescription only medicines and controlled drugs. 
•	Such other duties relating to the delivery of veterinary services as may be required from time to time. 
•	Act as the Veterinary Adviser in matters relating to DEFRA and CEFAS.
•	Ensure appropriate records are maintained. 
•	Contribute to the delivery of HO licence courses if/where required. 
•	Input advice into the University Animal Welfare and Ethical Review Body.
The full technical specification can be found in the ITT documentation which will be available after you have expressed your interest on In-Tend.

Title: 1806/347/EML/IMG/17 Machining Dynamometer
Description:
1806/347/EML/IMG/17  Machining Dynamometer
      
      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Machining Dynamometer on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Integrated Manufacturing Group, Factory 2050, Europa Way, Sheffield. S91ZA, South Yorkshire.
      
      Scope of Requirement:
      
      Supply of a system to enable measurement of a minimum of 3 components (Fx, Fy & Fz) of force during machining operations.
      
      The system will be used for measuring the cutting forces created by a 6-axis serial arm robot modified to perform large scale machining tasks. Due to the nature of the machining operations it is necessary for the force sensor to be able to withstand flood coolant.

Title: 1302/288/SW/F/15 Design, Installation and Set-up of High-accuracy Robotic Milling System
Description:
1302/288/SW/F/15 Design, Installation and Set-up of High-accuracy Robotic Milling System                   

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for the design, installation and set-up of High-accuracy Robotic Milling System for use within the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre's Factory 2050 at Europa Avenue, Sheffield

Scope of Requirement:

The AMRC wishes to change the method of CNC control for a KUKA Titan Robot to a system that will use external linear encoders and new kinematic control to provide a greatly increased accuracy of the robot’s movement, in paths and in motion. Several major hardware components are already owned or specified for order, new and unused, by the AMRC for this purpose:
 • KUKA KR1000 LR750 Titan Robot 
 • KRC4 Controller
 • Siemens 840DSL Machine Tool Controller
 • Renishaw RTLA-S self-adhesive absolute scale linear encoders with Resolute read-heads
Tenderer is to design and install a high-accuracy robotics system using high-accuracy external linear encoders to measure a KUKA Titan motion, the derivation of new kinematics, the design and build of a machining end-effector, plus the undertaking of a full setup, safety cell and calibration for this system.

Title: 5 Axis High Speed Machining Centre
Description:
2065/395/MY/MG/18  - 5 Axis High Speed Machining Centre 

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a 5 axis machine tool on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

This tender exercise is a re-publication of tender 1997/384/EML/AMRC/18 5 Axis High Speed Machining Centre which concluded without award due to failure in the specified lead time requirement.

This exercise is time critical; therefore tenderers are now required to state their best lead time for delivery, installation and commissioning. 

The University seeks to purchase a 5 axis machine tool that will support the AMRC's research into high accuracy prismatic simultaneous milling applications.

As the machine will be utilised for research projects rather than production, the usage will be subject to frequent change to suit different projects. The solution should therefore be readily and rapidly changeable to work on multiple applications.

The machine tool will allow manufacture of components in various materials, primarily aluminium but not excluding alloy steel and stainless steels.  The equipment should allow for machining with high pressure coolant.


Tender Process and Documentation:
This procurement is being conducted as an EU open procedure in accordance with the Regulations ( Public Contracts Regulations 2015).

Title: Reciprocating Broaching Units
Description:
1798/340/MY/AMRC/17      Reciprocating Broaching Units

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for Reciprocating Broaching Units (up to 3) on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Castings Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

The supply, installation and commissioning of a reciprocating broaching units for converting the rotary action of a lathe's driver lower turret to an axial reciprocating action for the single-point broaching of a spline tooth or other similar feature.  This equipment will be for use in manufacturing research, particularly of gear and transmission components for the aerospace, automotive and energy industries.

The University seeks to purchase reciprocating broaching units that will support the AMRC's research into gear cutting technologies for multifunctional machine tools.  AMRC's focus is on demonstrating opportunities for improved quality and accuracy in manufacture using single part setup for multiple operations.  The reciprocating broaching units should enable machining of internal and external splines in the same machine and setup as turning, milling and gear machining processes.  The units may also be utilised in the machining of gear teeth, keyways, fir-tree slots and other similar features.


Tender Process and Documentation:
This procurement is an open procedure carried out in accordance with  the Regulations ( Public Contracts Regulations 2015).

The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield

Title: Machine Tools x 3 Lots
Description:
1753/329/MY/AMRC/17 Machine Tools x 3 Lots

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for 3x Machine tools on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

The University seeks to purchase 3x machine tools that will support the AMRC's research into gear cutting technologies for multifunctional machine tools, including power skiving, hobbing, shaping, broaching and milling.  AMRC's focus is on demonstrating opportunities for improved quality and accuracy in manufacture using single part setup for multiple operations.

As the machines will be utilised for research projects rather than production, the usage will be subject to frequent change to suit different projects. The solution should therefore be readily and rapidly changeable to work on multiple applications.

The machine tools will allow manufacture of components in various materials, particularly including alloy steels, stainless steels, aluminium and nickel-based super alloys, as well as metal matrix composites and polymer composites.  The equipment should allow for machining with high pressure coolant of various types, as well as dry cutting.

Tender Process and Documentation:

Title: 2533/JN - Arbitrary Waveform Generator
Description:
The Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of Sheffield, with funding from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) requires an electrical waveform generator capable of producing arbitrary waveforms at GHz frequencies, and pulses of sub-nanosecond duration. The equipment will be used in two scenarios: a) creation of picosecond electrical pulses to drive an electro-optical modulator, in order to convert a continuous wave laser into an arbitrary pulsed source; b) creation of complex electrical pulse sequences for microwave-frequency manipulation of electrical charges in semiconductor quantum dots.

Title: 2623/488/MY/NAMRC/20 3D Printed Electronics System (3DPES) - AWARD
Description:
2623/488/MY/NAMRC/20        3D Printed Electronics System (3DPES)
      
      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a 3D Printed Electronics System (3DPES) on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Nuclear Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.
      
      Scope of Requirement
      The Nuclear AMRC (NAMRC) Digital Controls and Instrumentation Group have a need to develop a capability for rapid prototyping of electronic device designs. Developing this capability will support the strategic aim of the NAMRC to provide a world class agile digital product prototyping service and demonstrate to industry the opportunities for integrated agile digital product design in electronics.
      
      The technology identified to support this agile prototyping of complex electronic device designs is 3D Printed Electronics prototyping System (3DPES). This equipment shall provide a self-contained standalone capability demonstrating additively manufactured prototyping of Printed Electronics with highly complex 3D circuits.

Description:
2647/495/CW/CYMRU/20        Measuring Arm (with scanning & probing capabilities)
      
      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Measuring Arm (with scanning & probing capabilities) on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre CYMRU, Chester Road, Bretton, CH4 0DH.
      
      Scope of Requirement
      The AMRC CYMRU is looking for a measuring arm system with 3D scanning and probing capabilities that is able to measure many different surface types and qualities including carbon fibre, high-density foam and metallics. The parts that will be scanned will range from 0.01m*0.01m*0.01m to a 2.0m³.
      
      The solution should be supplied with or be able to link and integrate with a recognised external CAD package through software provided within the solution.
      
      The preference of the type of hardware solution would be an arm type with a scanner and touch probe, however if a solution is within budget and uses a different mounting technique this will not be deselected.

Title: 2480/480/MY/COM/20 Autonomous Guided Vehicle for AMRC Gear Centre - AWARD
Description:
2480/480/MY/COM/20 Autonomous Guided Vehicle for AMRC Gear Centre
      
      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Autonomous Guided Vehicle for AMRC Gear Centre on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.
      
      Scope of Requirement
      The supply of an autonomously guided vehicle (AGV), sometimes known as an autonomous mobile robot (AMR), to enable automated billet and component load/unload from machine tools, deburring equipment and measurement equipment.  This will enable 'lights-out' manufacturing demonstrations of gear and transmission components in the AMRC Gear Centre research facility, with a view to our partners adopting such technologies in production for a competitive advantage.
      A robot arm will be supplier mounted to the AGV, along with suitable end effectors for grabbing of gear and transmission components for loading and unloading to machine tools.

Title: 2370/DM - Negative Pressure Actinide Handling Glovebox
Description:
The Immobilisation Science Laboratory (ISL) is a world-leading centre for nuclear materials and nuclear waste immobilisation research. The ISL provides access to world-class expertise and facilities, thus enabling top-rate research in nuclear waste materials development and durability testing. This is achieved through a multi-material focus, encompassing ceramics, glass and cements, coupled with an understanding of their durability in aqueous media.  Through EPSRC investment the ISL will be developing a national user facility (HADES) for the materials science of radioactive waste management and disposal as part of the Sheffield hub.  This will build on previous investment of £3M by the Department of Energy and Climate Change and University of Sheffield to establish the allied MIDAS facility.

A dedicated Glovebox system for the handling and processing of uranium and thorium will strengthen the world-leading centre for nuclear materials research at the University of Sheffield.

Title: Autonomous Mobile Platforms
Description:
2550/011/CW/CYMRU/20       Autonomous Mobile Platforms  

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for Autonomous Mobile Platforms on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre CYMRU, Chester Road, Bretton, CH4 0DH.

Scope of Requirement
AMRC Cymru has a requirement for two (2) Autonomous Mobile Platform systems along with fleet management solution for use in research and development activities. These devices shall be delivered and commissioned at our facilities in Broughton, Flintshire, CH4 0DH. Equipment looking to be supplied will share charging equipment with each other, i.e. one (1) charging station for two (2) mobile autonomous platforms. Both mobile platforms and fleet manager system are to be able to interface with external systems and respond (and raise) software events for shop-wide Internet of Things and connectivity purposes with other machinery at AMRC Cymru.

Title: Humanoid Robot
Description:
2517/019/CW/CYMRU/20       Humanoid Robot  

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Humanoid Robot on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre CYMRU, Chester Road, CH4 0DH.
 
Scope of Requirement
AMRC Cymru has a requirement for a humanoid robotic system integrated with a serial robot arm for research, development and demonstration activities. These devices shall be delivered and commissioned at our facilities in Broughton, Flintshire, CH4 0DH.

The key output of the AMRC Cymru will be to advance the adoption, within Welsh industry, of advanced manufacturing technologies through the development of automation, digital or high value design solutions. This tender relates to the provision of facilities at AMRC Cymru to promote the further development of the food and drink industry in Wales.

The humanoid robot will act as the interface to connected systems allowing user inputs in various formats to be interpreted and used (voice, touchscreen) and to assist in disseminating output information to users. This includes, for this Tender, jogging the serial arm robot and programming via the humanoid robot interfaces.

Title: Polymer Material Jetting 3D Printer
Description:
2494/005/CW/CYMRU/20        Polymer Material Jetting 3D Printer  

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Polymer Material Jetting 3D Printer  on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (Wales), Chester Road, Bretton, CH4 0DH.

Scope of Requirement:

The AMRC Cyrmu site has been awarded grant funding to setup a centre for Sustainable packaging within the food and drink sector. The deliverables of this project are to create facilities to enable the development of new processes and facilitate innovative smart designs. Polymer material jetting 3D printing technology has been identified to fulfil the requirements as it potentially allows for the printing of multi-material and multi-colour parts including transparent materials. Through mixing of material graded materials with different mechanical properties can be produced. Furthermore this technology will be used to create casting patterns and tools for batch injection moulding.

This specification is aimed at purchasing equipment for use in the AMRC Wales research applications. It is expected that suppliers will provide long term support for the equipment including application engineering, programming and software upgrades.
The purchase of the technology also keeps with the ethos of putting the AMRC at the forefront of technology innovation within the manufacturing sector.

Description:
Mechanical Testing System
      
      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Mechanical Testing System on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, CYMRU.
      
      Scope of Requirement
      The mechanical test system will be used to assess the compliance of newly developed food packaging materials and technologies with current and future standards relating to the food industry. These standards may include some or all of those issued by BS/EN/ISO, ASTM, BRC etc.

Title: Vertical Lift Module Storage System
Description:
2501/010/CW/CYMRU/20   Vertical Lift Module Storage System  

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Vertical Lift Module Storage System on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre CYMRU, Chester Road, Bretton, CH4 0DH. 

Scope of Requirement

AMRC Cymru has a requirement for an automated vertical lift module (VLM) storage and retrieval system including installation thereof. This is a system for storing boxes and trays vertically to maximise work floor space. The trays / boxes will be retrieved automatically by the system based on user input (for specific trays or boxes). When operator inputs for a retrieval the VLM should locate and retrieve the item from the vertical stack and present them to the operator at the unloading bay.

The Vertical Lift Module will be required to communicate via a WCS, WMS or equivalent interface and communicate with other mobile and static robotic systems (agnostic) and conveyor systems.
Tenderer to offer technical assistance, training, commissioning and warranty for items specified

Title: Infrared Tracking Camera System
Description:
2499/007/CW/CYMRU/20        Infrared Tracking Camera System  

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for an Infrared Tracking Camera System on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre CYMRU, Chester Road, Bretton, CH4 0DH.

Scope of Requirement
The AMRC Cymru Group has a requirement for several High Accuracy motion capture systems using I.R. cameras to cover an area of 10m x 10m. The motion capture used will be Optical-Passive, using retroreflective markers that are tracked by the infrared cameras.

Tenderers are required to offer the correct quantity of cameras for the area specified, all hardware, cabling and sync box providing a single communication point between the cameras and PC. Tenderers are required to offer a software package capable of managing the data and will be the main point of interaction with the cameras and other components (if required), The software will be the main processing tool for all the 2D and 3D data.

Tenderers are required to offer advice on PC required as HD reference footage creates a huge amount of data, and displaying graphical information in 3D and real-time data processing asks a lot of the processor.  This system will be for use in creating a research cell dedicated to the automated tracking of production items through various cells.

As this cells will be used as a research platform, it must offer a means of controlling the cameras within highly functional user interface and real time data with minimal latency. Tenderers are required to offer technical assistance, training, commissioning and warranty for items specified. The equipment's overview requirements are to supply, install, commission and provide training for minimum 3 staff to operate the motion capture system, latest version software.  

Tender Process and Documentation:
This procurement is an open procedure conducted in accordance with the Public Contracts Regulations 2015

Title: 2406/JS - 3D Bioprinter
Description:
The University of Sheffield is out to tender on behalf of the Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering for a 3D Bioprinter.

Scope of Requirement:

Our work concentrates on the fabrication of interconnected sensors and actuators that enable multi-modal interfaces with biological systems. These can be applied for studying of individual cells or tissues such as the heart, brain or nerves. From a technological point of view this requires microfabrication tools capable of handling technological and biological materials at the micro- and meso- scale. These can be silicones, hydrogels, composites, suspensions of biological cells or functional microparticles. One example is the fabrication of arrays of electrodes, optical waveguides and microfluidic channels in designs adapted for implantation in the soft tissues of the nervous system. These soft bioelectronic implants are then used to stimulate or record biological activity. To enable these objectives we require a versatile additive manufacture platform capable of handing a palette of materials using various printing technologies


The full technical specification can be found in the tender documentation which will be sent to you once you have expressed your interest.

Title: 2405/465/CW/CYMRU/19 Polymer Powder Bed Fusion 3D Printer  - AWARD
Description:
2405/465/CW/CYMRU/19        Polymer Powder Bed Fusion 3D Printer
      
      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Polymer Powder Bed Fusion 3D Printer on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Wales. 
      
      Scope of Requirement
      The new AMRC Wales facility located in NE Wales and has a requirement to be able to rapidly produce prototypes of designs for examination and has identified that 3D Printing is the best method of achieving this criteria. We are looking to purchase an advanced polymer 3D printer to enhance the capability of our centre and gain knowledge which we can pass onto our customers, partners and local SME's in rapid prototyping, advanced manufacturing and 3D printing. The contract will cover the consumables of the printer for a 4 year period, however there are no guaranteed volumes of purchase.
      
      The machine is required to meet a high demand, provide scope for expansion in the future, and also demonstrate how the technology can replace some traditional equipment. The machine will be used to provide 3D printed components to support research and development projects being carried out at the AMRC Wales facility (AMRC/Cymru, Chester Road, Bretton, Flintshire, CH4 ODH).

Title: 2357/JN - 360kW Multi-Source Bi-Directional Converter
Description:
The University of Sheffield is a leading institution in energy research. The focus of the research in this tender is on electrically powered rail transport systems and electric road vehicles (EVs), and extends to the power supply network which supports them.
The proposed research, supported by funding from the EPSRC, addresses both the technology to store electric energy in a form suited to transport use, and the modelling to understand how to use the technology to reduce overall energy demand.

This tender is for a multi-source bi-directional DC/DC converter that is suitable for the connection of multiple energy sources that can export and import power to a DC train power network.

The scope of supply for this tender includes the DC/DC converter(s), DC breaker, DC contactor, 90kW dump resistor, protection devices (over voltage/over current) and busbars for making connections.

This is an Non-EU open exercise. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University's e-tendering system http://in-tendhost.co.uk/sheffield

Title: Combined Heat & power (CHP) Biomass Gasifier
Description:
With co-funding from the European Regional Development Fund, the University of Sheffield is establishing a flagship national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) to provide a multi-technology, integrated research, development and deployment platform, encompassing a portfolio of facilities focusing on low-carbon energy generation and carbon capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS) technologies, integrated together with an overarching smart energy management system. 

The Gasifier will complement existing and planned capabilities to provide a demonstrator of low-carbon technologies and to support a wide range of research activities, such as fuel development, system tolerances, gas clean-up, syngas utilisation, and integrated systems operation.

The equipment will be located at the following University of Sheffield address:

Title: 2302/JN - Motion Analyses Laboratory for Mice
Description:
The University of Sheffield with funding from the EPSRC requires a motion analyses laboratory to perform state of the art research into mouse gait. 

The equipment here requested will be the core of a motion analyses laboratory for mice. The final system should be integrated with cameras for motion capture, force plate for ground force analyses and a pressure mattress to measure the pressure that the animal induces to the ground. The system should also include the hardware and software to analyse the movement of the animal and integrate the synchronised outputs from the load and pressure measurements.

Title: 2243/HP - Thermogravimetric Analyser and Differential Scanning Calorimeter (TG-DSC)
Description:
The University of Sheffield is out to purchase a Thermogravimetric Analyser and Differential Scanning Calorimeter (TG-DSC) for the Department of Materials Science and Engineering. 

The required instrument must be capable of simultaneously analysing heat flow and changes in mass under heating. This enables the identification of phase transitions, structural transitions, thermal events such as combustion, significant mass loss events (e.g. loss of water from a system) and volatilisation of elements during heating. This range of information is vital for understanding the novel synthetic routes under development, and will also give insights into the kinetic vs thermodynamic processes which govern synthesis of functional materials. This covers a huge variety of timely research, in the case for functional oxides, including Li-ion and Na-ion battery materials, thermoelectrics, piezoelectrics, and future materials for fusion. Functional oxides are of perennial interest and are currently an area for growth with e.g. the EPSRC.

The full specification and ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield

Title: 2269/438/JN/COMP/19 Supply of a Tool Pre-Setting Machine - AWARD
Description:
2269/438/JN/COMP/19        Tool Pre-Setting Machine 
      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Tool Pre-Setting Machine  on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.
      
      Scope of Requirement
      A tool pre-setting machine in its basic form is required to ensure that cutting tool lengths and radii are captured and accounted for prior to any machining activities.
      In addition to this, the AMRC requires the capability to inspect and measure the various mechanisms of tool wear induced through machining on cutting tools with a variety of geometries, with minimal user input, for repeatable and reproducible results.

Title: 3D Printers (2 Lots)
Description:
2169/429/MY/NAMRC/18       3D Printers (2 Lots) 


The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for 3D Printers (2 Lots) on behalf of the Nuclear Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Midlands.

Scope of Requirement
The new Nuclear AMRC facility located in the Midlands has a requirement to be able to rapidly produce prototypes of designs for examination and has identified that 3D Printing is the best method of achieving this criteria.

Because of this, we are looking to purchase four 3D printing technologies to enhance the capability of our centre and gain knowledge which we can pass onto our customers, partners and local SME's in rapid prototyping, advanced manufacturing and 3D printing.

The lots are required to meet a high demand, provide scope for expansion in the future, and also demonstrate how the technology can replace some traditional equipment. The machines will be used to provide 3D printed components in an expanded range of materials to support research and development projects being carried out at the Nuclear AMRC Midlands facility

Title: Optical Shaft Measurement System
Description:
2097/406/MY/COM/18        Optical Shaft Measurement System  

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a n Optical Shaft Measurement System on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

Title: 2112/405/CW/NW/18 3D Printers (3 Lots)
Description:
2112/405/CW/NW/18      3D Printers (3 Lots) 

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for 3D Printers (3 Lots)  on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

One of the core areas for the new AMRC North West centre will be to assist and provide guidance to the local Lancashire SME community. From initial canvasing of SME's in the area we have identified that 3D printing is an area with a large amount of immediate interest. 
Because of this, we are looking to purchase three 3D printing technologies to enhance the capability and gain knowledge to pass on to these SME's.

The three lots are required to meet a high demand, provide scope for expansion in the future, and also demonstrate how the technology can replace some traditional equipment. The machines will be used to provide 3D printed components in an expanded range of materials to all research and SME engagement projects across the AMRC North West.

Title: 3D Scanning Solution
Description:
2068/387/EML/COM/18        3D Scanning Solution                                          


The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a 3D Scanning Solution on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Composites Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement
The AMRC with Boeing, Composites Centre is looking for a 3D scanning solution to allow use to scan many different surface types and qualities including carbon fibre and high density foam. The parts that will be scanned will range from 0.01m*0.01m*0.01m to 5m*2m*2m.

The solution should also be able to link to a recognised external CAD package through software provided within the solution.
The solution also needs to have to ability to adaptively control and change and update machining programs to allow true dimensional accurate parts to be made.

Title: Metal Additive Manufacturing System
Description:
1998/385/EML/DPG/18        Metal Additive Manufacturing System 

The University of Sheffield, Design Prototyping Group (DPG) wishes to invite tenders for the provision of a Metal Additive Manufacturing System (MAMS). 

Scope of Requirement

The system should be capable of building complex three dimensional metal parts directly from a CAD data file through sequential addition of metal powder in layers, which is then subsequently melted.

The MAMS will be used to design and manufacture prototype components for a range of applications catering to industries such as aerospace, medical, space and automotive.  The MAMS must be able to process reactive powders in a safe environment either through integrated ATEX rated sieving capability (preferred) or an external closed looped sieve system (compatible with MAMS).

The Advanced Structural Testing Centre (ASTC) is a research and development testing facility that holds a UKAS accreditation for in-house methods. Title: Composite Ready CNC Lathe
Description:
1999/386/EML/COM/18 - Composite Ready CNC Lathe

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a composite capable lathe on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Composites Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

The Composite Machining Group, are tendering for the supply, installation and commissioning of a composite capable lathe with multi-axis milling ability suitable for both wet and dry CNC turning/milling of primarily composite materials as well as capability in metal materials for mould tool applications.

The equipment will support the AMRC's Composite Centre fundamental research into technologies such as machinability, dynamics and process monitoring of composite/metallic cylindrical parts.  The equipment should have adequate robustness, high precision and repeatability to facilitate the manufacture of high performance aerospace, automotive and similar parts with demanding tolerance requirements.

The equipment should have adequate robustness, high precision and repeatability to facilitate the manufacture of high performance aerospace components demanding tolerance requirements. Machine should allow machining in wet, MQL as well as dry cutting environments.

The machine should have at least simultaneous 4 axes of motion X-Z-Y-C or 5 axes with the X-Z-Y-C-B axis or similar comparable configuration. The machine should be able to drill in the vertical/horizontal plane and angular increments between planes.

It is planned to have the machine with extraction system, however, if it exceeds the budget limit it can be considered as optional. The AMRC Composite Centre in the future may wish to install a dedicate extraction system for the machine. The supplier is required to commit technical support in this installation and warranty cover. 

All appropriate peripheral equipment to ensure the health and safety of operators, electrical equipment and machine tool components.  While the liability for cutting potentially hazardous materials lies with the customer, the supply of equipment to enable the safety is expected to be dealt with in the tenderer's solution.

Description:

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Composite Kit Cutting Conveyorised Bed Machine on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Composite Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

The AMRC Composite Centre is looking to procure a composite kit cutting machine for the cutting of flat patterns from both dry and pre-preg composite materials. The machine shall be of the general "conveyorised vacuum bed" type, using a combination of drag knives or driven tools to allow the cutting of various composite materials.

The machine is not required to be capable of cutting honeycomb core.
The machine will primarily be used for research and development activity supporting industrial applications ranging from Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 1 - 6.  Application sectors will likely be, but are not limited to, aerospace, automotive, medical and marine.

Title: 1904/367/EML/COM/17        Robotic Stitching and Trimming Cell
Description:
1904/367/EML/COM/17        Robotic Stitching and Trimming Cell

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Robotic Stitching and Trimming Cell on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Castings Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

A robotic stitching and trimming cell is required. 
The cell will be used for stitching together complex shaped textile preforms (predominately carbon fibre) of geometries typically found in the aerospace and automotive industries. 

Stitching is likely to be required in these preforms for 5 main reasons:
•	Joining together of smaller shaped preforms into one large preform.
•	Stitching the edges to stabilise them.
•	Stitching around inserts or foam cores to locate them.
•	Stitching in specific places to control fibre movement or prevent wrinkling during forming processes.
•	Stitching in specific places to prevent fibre movement in subsequent resin injection processes.

The cell will also have the capability to change the stitching head on the robot with an ultrasonic knife allowing the preform boundaries to be accurately cut.

The cell will be mainly used for stitching and trimming of carbon fibre fabric preforms with geometries typical to those found in the automotive and aerospace industries. Glass and Kevlar fabrics may also need to be stitched. Stitching threads will be carbon, Kevlar, polyester or other thermoplastics. Due to the presence of electrically conductive carbon fibre the equipment should be suitably protected from conductive dust ingress.

Tender Process and Documentation:
This procurement is an EU open procedure carried out in accordance with  the Regulations ( Public Contracts Regulations 2015).

The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield

Title: 1834/356/MY/COM/17 High Tension Filament Winder
Description:
1834/356/MY/COM/17     Filament Winder

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a High Tension Filament Winder on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Composites Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.


Scope of Requirement

The AMRC would like to expand its filament winding capability to include high temperature processing coupled with high tension capability to allow the manufacture of thermoplastic thick walled composite components as well as many other applications in the aerospace, automotive, energy & industrial markets.  The new equipment may also add a host of other capabilities not present on current equipment such as high pre-tensioning of mandrels, vessel liner pressurisation, ability to use delicate mandrels, integrated mandrel heating, binder spray system and even fibre placement technology.

Title: Payload Robots x 2 Lots
Description:
1814/349/MY/IMG/17       Payload Robots x 2 Lots

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for 2 x Payload Robots on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Castings Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement:

LOT 1:
The supply, installation and commissioning of a small-scale, high-speed robot system. This should handle roughly 7kg payload max (and roughly half this even at full speed of at least 360 degrees/s), and included all required services. It requires 6 DoF movement, at least 6 axis, and should be capable of high-speed operation. This device is for use within the AMRC Factory 2050 building.

LOT 2:
The supply, installation and commissioning of an industrial collaborative robot ("cobot") system, with at roughly 14kg payload and services included for running of electrical signals to the end effector. It requires 6 DoF movement, at least 6 axis, and features safe joint-torque for possible use with human operators without a safety cell.

Title: Tailored Fibre Placement Machine
Description:
1819/353/EML/COM/17      Tailored Fibre Placement Machine

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Tailored Fibre Placement Machine on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Composites Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement
This tender is for the supply, installation and commissioning (including all necessary training) of a tailored fibre placement (TFP) machine.  The equipment will be used to create near net shape preforms for composites applications.  The machine should be capable of working with carbon fibre, and capable of creating preforms up to 8mm thick.  This machine will be used to lay technical fibres (such as carbon, glass, Kevlar, commingled materials, and wires) on various substrate materials (such as films, non wovens, wovens, non-crimp fabrics).  The machine will use carbon predominantly, so electrical proofing is essential. 

Tender Process and Documentation:
This procurement is a non EU open procedure carried out in accordance with  the Regulations ( Public Contracts Regulations 2015).

Title: 3D Printers x 3 Lots
Description:
1802/345/MY/AMRC/17       3D Printers x 3 Lots

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for 3D Printers x 3 Lots on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Design and Prototyping Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

The Design and Prototyping Group (DPG) operate a site wide Free Access 3D printing scheme, open to all AMRC employees.  Free Access enables 3D printing design and process knowledge to spread throughout the AMRC triggering increased use cases.  Backed by user data, the success of the scheme has lead to an increase in demand for equipment.  

The Three Lots are required to meet increased demand, provide scope for scheme expansion, and also replace worn equipment. The machines will be used to provide 3D printed components in an expanded range of materials to all research projects across the AMRC.

This specification is aimed at purchasing equipment for use in AMRC research applications. It is expected that suppliers will provide long term support for the equipment including application engineering, programming and software upgrades.

Scope of Requirement:
LOT 1 : Fused Deposition Modelling (FDM) 3D printer with composite filament fabrication.
LOT 2 : Fused Deposition Modelling (FDM) 3D printer cell 
LOT 3 : Stereolithography (SLA) Polymer 3D printer cell 


Tender Process and Documentation:

      The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for the supply of equipment to the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Integrated Manufacturing Group, Factory of the Future, South Yorkshire.

Title: Refurbishment of Machine Tool - Cincinnati H5-800
Description:
1771/338/MY/AMRC/17     
Refurbishment of Machine Tool - Cincinnati H5-800 

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Refurbishment of Machine Tool - Cincinnati H5-800on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement

Refurbishment and upgrading of the Cincinnati H5-800 machine tool belonging to the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre with Boeing (AMRC). This machine tool offers a mechanically stable machining platform but requires refurbishment to ensure it offers optimum mechanical performance. Furthermore, the electrical system requires upgrading to provide the latest control system features such as those seen on modern machine tools.
As the AMRC is a research establishment, an essential requirement of the refurbishment is the addition of, or providing the facility to add, a number of sensors to the machine tool.

Title: Heat Treatment Furnace
Description:
1773/339/EML/NAMTEC/17 Heat Treatment Furnace

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a Heat Treatment Furnace on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Castings Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

Scope of Requirement:

The requirement is for a vacuum heat treatment furnace, which is able to heat treat components in titanium, nickel and iron based alloys, of up to 300 mm x 300 mm x 300 mm size, up to a maximum temperature of 1300 °C.
The vacuum heat treatment furnace must be capable of operating within the constraints of a class 4 furnace to SAE AMS 2750 and SAE AMS 2769 with Type B instrumentation.
 
All the equipment shall be surface mounted avoiding any special civil works.
The equipment supplied must be designed to be as economical to run as possible 
Tenderers shall propose their best solution to address this specification of requirement.

Title: 5 Axis Milling Machine
Description:
1739/333/MY/MG/17 5 Axis Milling Machine

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for a 5 Axis Milling Machine on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre, Machining Group at Catcliffe, South Yorkshire.

This tender is for the supply, installation and commissioning of a 5-axis milling machine for use in tool wear, coolant, and machining studies.  The equipment will be used for testing and demonstration purposes in the AMRC's Factory of the Future.  The equipment should have the ability to machine numerous materials from the aerospace, automotive and other high value manufacturing industries; including Titanium, Nickel based alloys and high strength steel, etc.  The equipment will also support the AMRC's fundamental research into technologies such as machinability, dynamics and process monitoring.

Title: 1625/325/ML/COM/17 In-Line Heating Equipment for High Speed, High Temperature Filament Winding & Advanced Fibre Placement
Description:
1625/325/ML/COM/17 In-Line Heating Equipment for High Speed, High Temperature Filament Winding & Advanced Fibre Placement
      
      The University of Sheffield wished to invite tenders for an In- Line Heating System for High speed, High Temperature Filament Winding and Advanced Fibre placement, for supply to the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre's, new Composites Facility.
      
      Scope of Requirement:
      
      The AMRC with Boeing have both Filament Winding (FW) and Advanced Fibre Placement (AFP) capability for the manufacture of advanced composite components with both thermoset and thermoplastic matrix materials. 
      
      The AMRC require a heating system which can be mounted onto the existing filament winding machine head to allow the in-process melting & consolidation of thermoplastic composite materials at high temperature.
      
      The system should allow the melting of thermoplastic materials in either prepreg or commingled formats, with a melting point up to 350oC and should be capable of running with material feed rates of up to 1m/s for lower temperature melt materials.
      
      
      Tender Process and Documentation:
      
      This is an open tender exercise. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield

Title: 1448/MR Appointment of Services Engineer for building of a covered storage facility
Description:
Tender Opportunity 1448/MR


The project is for the building of a covered storage facility with crane capacity of 50 Tonne. This is the ideal solution although a lower rating of crane may be acceptable if 50 Tonne is not possible due to site conditions and ground bearing capacities.
 

The objective is to provide a facility on a location on the Nuclear AMRC site that can store tests piece, materials and equipment to a weight of 50 Tonne. A feasibility study is required to determine the optimum location considering logistics of handling large items and budget constraints.  There are two site locations which would be suitable but each with different ground bearing capacities and access issues.
 

The project for which you are bidding will comprise a c300sm single storey storage facility either as an extension to the existing NAMRC building or a stand alone unit adjacent to the existing HGV access road.

The University of Sheffield is looking for suitably qualified and competent persons to undertake this work

This is an open non EU procurement procedure. The ITT and full specification can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University's e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield. Completed tenders must be returned through the same e-tendering system.

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for the supply of Integrated Instrumentation Monitoring and Control Solution for use within the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre's Nuclear Group at Catcliffe in Rotherham.

The Nuclear AMRC is seeking an integrated instrumentation monitoring and control solution for its Bulk AM process. Description:
1297/292/EML/N/15 X-Ray Diffractometer system for residual stress measurement
  
The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for supply to the Nuclear Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre at Catcliffe in Rotherham.

Scope of Requirement:

One of the recurrent needs is evaluating the residual stress left on finished work-pieces. In order to support the research an X-Ray Diffractometer (XRD) measuring system, for evaluation of surface stress and stress profiling, is required.

The system should be capable of evaluate surface residual stress in a non-destructive manner, an electro polishing device should be included for stress profiling. The system should be able to perform quick measurements in view of the high request for measurements that is foreseen.

Title: 2082/JN - Small Scale Strip Caster
Description:
The Sheffield Royce Institute is a~£34M project based in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering. Sheffield is part of the national Henry Royce Institute (with the main Hub in Manchester) which aims to grow the UK world-leading research and innovation base in advanced materials science, fundamental to all industrial sectors and the national economy. The Sheffield Royce Institute focuses on Advanced Materials Processing and will be delivered through two centres - the Royce Discovery Centre (RDC) and the Royce Translational Centre (RTC). These state of the art facilities will allow materials discovery, materials manufacturing and prototype production and will act as an open access centre of excellence for the UK.

As part of the Henry Royce Institute for Advanced Materials, the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at The University of Sheffield would like to purchase a small-scale strip caster with the capacity to melt up to about 100g of various metals and alloys and to produce width of ribbons up to 20mm. 

This small-scale strip caster is to support the materials discovery strand of the Henry Royce theme.

Description:
The University of Sheffield is out to tender on behalf of the Department of Corporate Information and Computing Services for a Digital Audio-Visual Media Hosting and Delivery System.

The University wishes to maximise its use of audio visual media to support and promote the University’s mission across all its main strategic areas. Specifically, this is in the key areas of learning and teaching, dissemination of research, public engagement and marketing/promotional activities.

Title: Summative Assessment for the Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC)
Description:
The University of Sheffield (UoS) with support funding from ERDF is establishing a £3m Translational Energy Research Centre as an open access to business and academic users to a) provide innovation facilities to support local enterprises to develop low carbon energy products, and boost cooperation with research institutes;and b) demonstrate low carbon energy technologies.  

As part of the project, the University will procure equipment to be housed at an existing university facility in Beighton near Sheffield.  In additional to capital investment, a revenue budget of £950k has been allocated to support facilities operation and research support for enterprises.

We are looking for an experienced consultant or organisation to carry out an interim Summative Assessment to satisfy ERDF compliance in accordance with ERDF summative assessment guidance and appendices (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/evaluation-of-the-european-regional-development-fund-2014-to-2020).

Title: 1903/LM - Linen Hire and Laundering Service (ACS)
Description:
Note: Alternative contract period for bids (ITT amended 23/03/2018)
We invite bids on the original contract period of 1 year + optional 3 years + optional 1 year, but if better value can be obtained across a 2 year + optional 2 year + optional 1 year contract, then please detail these costs separately in your bid. This is to offer bidders a higher security option on the contract.
______________________________________________________________________________________________
The University of Sheffield Accommodation and Commercial Services (ACS) wishes to appoint a customer facing company for the provision of a linen (Laundry and/or Hire) service who can provide an excellent service that is efficient and reliable.  The services provided by the successful contractor are key to those provided to our customers, and as such the University requires a company who can respond to its needs, sometimes at very short notice.

The primary business of ACS is the accommodation of its student residents, however during the summer months or in times of lower than anticipated demand for this accommodation, it also operates an ever expanding conference service and business.  
It is this business which requires the laundering of ACS's owned linen and furnishings (e.g. sheets, towels, curtains), and also the hire of linen (e.g. sheets and towels).  Whilst the majority of the business requirement is currently through the summer months, there may also be an ad-hoc requirements during term time laundering.  Such summer business can vary from conferences of a few hundred people, to 3000+, however the larger conferences are often planned with at least 1 years' notice.

The service to be provided will include the provision of linen (hire and potentially purchase), delivery and collection to and from specific agreed locations.  Minimum notification times will be agreed between the parties. The contract is based on an initial 1 year, followed by an optional further 3 years, and optional final 1 year, subject to satisfactory performance.

Your tender response must be submitted through the University's on line e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sheffield to arrive by the date and time specified in the ITT document. Late tenders will not be considered.

Title: Weather Stations (Urban Flows project)
Description:
The University of Sheffield Urban Flows Observatory, led by the Departments of Civil and Structural and Automatic Control and Systems Engineering, is looking to create a network of weather stations around the city of Sheffield. These will operate for an initial period of 5 years.

The purpose is to provide measurements to support data gathered from a network of air quality sensors as well as information regarding solar irradiance and inform research regarding the Urban Heat Island effect. These sensors will be deployed concurrently but mainly at locations different to the weather stations.

The proposed unit for the meteorological observations should be self-contained and with limited maintenance requirements, using radar-based precipitation measurement.

The locations for the stations will be primarily schools within the area of Sheffield city and in most cases mains power and network connectivity (Ethernet wired or wireless) will be available.

Title: 2366/JN - High Performance Liquid Chromatography Machine
Description:
The Partridge Group based within the Chemistry department at the University of Sheffield has been awarded an EPSRC grant to develop a Cu-catalysed amination reaction of alkylboronic esters. The products of these reactions, alkyl amines, are high value products commonly found in biologically active molecules such as pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals. Part of the project involves developing asymmetric amination methods. We therefore require the ability to measure the enantiomeric excess of the chemicals made. The University is seeking to purchase an analytical HPLC (High-Performance Liquid Chromatography) machine, to use in conjunction with chiral phase analytical columns.

This is a mini-competition under Lot 4 (Liquid Chromatographs) of the APUC Framework Agreement for: Supply of Mass Spectrometry and Chromatography Equipment LAB1016AP

Title: 2292/DM - Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) - for online detection of entrained metal aerosols in flue/process gases

With co-funding from the European Regional Development Fund, the University of Sheffield is establishing a flagship national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) to provide a multi-technology, integrated research, development and deployment platform, encompassing a portfolio of facilities focusing on low-carbon energy generation and carbon capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS) technologies, integrated together with an overarching smart energy management system.

To establish the Centre, the University of Sheffield is looking to procure a wide range of equipment focusing on bioenergy, renewable energy and CCUS technologies - with an extensive supporting infrastructure of a suite of analytical facilities. This tender document is specifically focused on the procurement of an inductively coupled plasma (ICP), which will be used online to assess the species and levels of entrained metal aerosols in the flue gases from on-site various systems.

Title: 2057/JN - Architect Services for the Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC)
Description:
The University of Sheffield (UoS) will establish a national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) at the (Advanced Manufacturing Research Campus) AMRC in the Innovation District. In line with both regional and national innovation priorities TERC will provide facilities to develop low carbon technologies as both individual processes and as part of integrated energy systems. This will be achieved by installing renewable energy generation, bioenergy and smart grid equipment in, and bringing an enhanced Pilot-Scale Advanced CO2-Capture Technology facility to, a bespoke building.  The building will be circa 1,600sqm with 400sqm of covered external storage and 900sqm of external area for equipment plis associated car parking, service yard and landscaping.  Their will be circa 20-24 pieces of equioment.  The approximate value of the construction works is £4m for the base build plus £2m for the shell enhancment for the supply and connection of services to the research equipment.

The University is thus seeking an experienced and qualified Architect to provide Architectural Services the principal role being to Provide all services expected of a competent Architect including but not limited to: 
•	Design, develop and document all architectural elements via drawings, models, schedules and specifications, including advising on quality control during contract 
•	Act as lead designer in the development of co-ordinated design work with other consultants to successfully complete the Project. 


This is an OJEU Tender and funded by ERDF
Full tender documents can be accessed via in-tend: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/sheffield/aspx/Home
Expressions of interest available until 31/8/18 17:00 (UK Time)
Closure of Tender 3/9/18 12:00 Noon (UK Time)
