Title: 210/YE Chemical Pilot Plant tender
Description:
The University of Sheffield is out to tender on behalf of the Faculty of Engineering - Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, for a Chemical Pilot Plant.

The closing date for return of Pre-qualification Questionnaires is Monday 4th April 2016 at 12 noon (GMT)

The Diamond Pilot Plant (DiPP) will be the cornerstone for the education of The Sheffield Chemical Engineer.  Future engineers will use, test and explore integrated processes with state of the art simulations and world class control systems in a safe, product oriented environment.  They will develop as engineers immersed in physical and virtual systems that address some of the key grand challenges of this century: Energy and climate change, affordable medicines, and bioengineered products.

Chemical Product Engineering:  Traditionally chemical engineers are process engineers.  21th century chemical engineers need to be both product and process engineers who develop new products, as well as design the processes that manufacture them.  DiPP is a unique learning environment for product as well as process engineering, where students learn to develop, characterize and reverse engineer new products for high value manufacturing, biotechnology, and clean fuels.

Lot 1- Power to X pilot plant to convert renewable energy to environmentally friendly diesel fuel
Lot 2 - High value manufacturing - continuous manufacture of pharmaceutical solid oral dosage forms
Lot 3 - Industrial Control room

Suppliers are invited to submit tenders for one or multiple Lots.

The technical specifications can be found in the tender documentation which will be sent to you once you have expressed your interest. 

This tender is being conducted under the Competitive Process with Negotiation. Suppliers should first complete and submit the PQQ, and refer to the draft ITN stage and accompanying documents, which provide the detailed specifications required.

Title: Compound Microscope
Description:
The University of Sheffield requires a Compound Microscope to form part of the build of a fluorescence microscope for the purpose of imaging proteins or protein aggregates at 'single molecule resolution' in solutions, cells and sectioned tissue (with light sheet imaging in Epi mode) in 3D and which also allows us to perform localisation based super-resolution microscopy (like STORM, DNA-PAINT etc) in 2D in (using total internal reflection mode)  

We would like to build this set-up using an inverted motorised microscope body with very high flexibility, equipped with high-numerical aperture objective (to study at high resolution), an auto-focus system (allows long time experiment without any drift) and an automated stage (to image image multiple regions of the samples). 

To compliment the Compound Microscope multiple lasers (4 different colours) and a highly sensitive camera will be purchased separately and added by the University. 

In the near future we will add new optical modules in such a way that we can do label free imaging of single proteins.


This is an non-EU open exercise.

Notice Identifier: 2557/DM - Rotating Packed Bed, Co2 Capture Plant / Award
Title: Rotating Packed Bed, Co2 Capture Plant
Description: At the University of Sheffield, we are setting up a National Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) and are looking to procure a wide range of new equipment focusing on bioenergy, renewable energy and carbon capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS) technologies. Flue gas from all combustion systems will be integrated into the on-site carbon capture plants. The captured Co2 will be utilised in an on-site Fischer-Tropsch plant along with hydrogen generated on-site from renewable resources in order to produce green fuel for use in the turbines/engines for full-chain CCUS demonstration. As part of the equipment portfolio we are looking to procure a Rotating Packed Bed (RPB) Co2 capture system that can separate Co2 from flue gases generated by coal/ biomass/gas fired combustion systems and industrial sources, to broaden and support our extensive research, development and deployment activities at the centre.

Title: Pulsed UV laser
Description:
The University of Sheffield is out to tender on behalf of the Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering for components which seek  to perform in-situ laser lithography inside a semiconductor reactor. This  tender is for a pulsed UV visible laser system to perform the interference lithography. The primary wavelength should be between 300 and 400nm, the pulse width in the 0.5-10ns regime, the pulse energy a minimum of 200mJ and the pulse frequency in the 10 to 25Hz range. Beam quality, stability and divergence are critical aspects for our application and are detailed below in our minimum requirements

The University believes the specification may be met using two technologies. However we are open to all options

(i)	Lamp or diode pumped frequency multiplier Nd/YAG laser
(ii)	Excimer laser

Title: 2389/JN - Upgrading of Biomass Boiler to Support Waste to Energy Combustion
Description:
With co-funding from the European Regional Development Fund, the University of Sheffield is establishing a flagship national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) to provide a multi technology, integrated research and development platform, focusing on low-carbon energy generation and carbon capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS) technologies. This tender document is specifically focused on the procurement of equipment to extend the capability of an existing biomass boiler to support waste-to energy (WtE) combustion. At present, we have a Gilles-HPKI-R 240 kWth grate boiler that can fire a range of chipped biomass fuels. The aim is to expand the capability of this system to a WTE boiler to enable the combustion of a wider range of fuels, including drier pelletised fuels, as well as fuels that are classed as 'clean waste', including:

- vegetable waste from agriculture or forestry,
- vegetable waste from the food processing industry,
- untreated non-hazardous wood waste (formerly known as Grade A recycled wood)

The new WTE system will provide a demonstrator of low-carbon technologies and to support a wide range of research activities.

The overall specification is divided into 3 parts to be awarded as one contract:

Part 1: Fuel silo and conveying system;

Part 2: High-efficiency electrostatic precipitator (ESP);

Part 3: Flue gas stack with flue gas extraction.

Suppliers are requested to offer a complete solution in their return, including offers to all 3 parts of the tender.

Title: 2559/JN - High Pressure Heat Exchanger Testbed
Description:
The University of Sheffield (UoS) with funding from European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Department for Business Energy and Industrial Strategy is establishing a Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) to support and promote low carbon energy technology development, validation and uptake. To complement our research capability, we are looking to procure a high pressure heat exchanger (HPHE) test bed.

The high pressure, high temperature heat exchanger (HEX) test bed is aimed at supporting R and D in high-efficiency power conversion cycles, focussing on supercritical CO2 (sCO2) for oxy-fired gas cycles (Allam cycle) but also with global applications in other power and industrial sectors. The objective is to establish a flexible test loop ideally capable of operating at pressures up to 370 bar, support R and D in oxy-fired gas cycles, but in general it is envisaged the facility will enable the study of high efficiency heat exchangers covering areas such as heat transfer, pressure drop, thermal stresses, and impact of phase changes, impurities, fouling, corrosion and materials research. It will provide performance data for the sCO2 cycle to model and evaluate designs, e.g. heat exchanger sizing. We are estimating tender submissions of between GBP 300 000 and GBP 400 000. The GBP 350 000 figure shown indicates the mid range value for this project.

Title: 2419/DM - Thin Film Deposition System
Description:
As part of the Sir Henry Royce Institute (SHRI) for Materials, the Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Sheffield wishes to open tender for a thin film deposition system. The primary function of the system will be to allow the exploration of new materials as either homogeneous single layer films or multilayer stacks. Film thicknesses should be controllable to monolayer levels, such that the system can be used to fabricate ultra-thin films.

Initially the system will be targeted at the exploration of high entropy metal alloys, amorphous/crystalline "nanocomposite" metallic coatings for wear and corrosion protection, magnetic thin films and multilayers, and electro-ceramic materials, however we anticipate the system's reach may extend as we make access available to external users through the SHRI.

Title: 2239/DM - Hydrogen Electrolyser
Description:
With co-funding from the European Regional Development Fund, the University of Sheffield is establishing a flagship national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) and is looking to procure and integrate into a mini-grid system a range of bioenergy and renewable energy generating equipment Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage (CCUS), fuel cells and electrolysers. Hydrogen is a fundamental element in the transition to low carbon (or hydrogen) economy and hydrogen generation will form a key part of the integrated infrastructure in the Centre. This capability will support R&D activities associated hydrogen utilisation as fuel and/ or energy store, and as a transformational feedstock. 

The hydrogen generated will be utilised: (i) as fuel for a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell and/or fuel-cell-based micro combined heat and power (CHP) systems; (ii) additive to conventional fuels for energy generation; and (iii) for carbon dioxide utilisation applications such as liquid/gaseous fuel generation. Therefore, as part of the equipment portfolio, we are looking to procure an electrolyser capable of generating ≥ 20 Nm3/hr (preferably ≥ 30 Nm3/hr) of Hydrogen and associated hydrogen storage of minimum 300Nm3/h.

The closing date for tender returns is at 12 noon on 3rd June 2019 (UK time)

Title: 2238/DM - Stationery PEM Fuel Cell
Description:
With co-funding from the European Regional Development Fund, the University of Sheffield is establishing a flagship national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) and is looking to procure and integrate into a mini-grid system a range of bioenergy and renewable energy generating equipment Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage (CCUS), fuel cells and electrolysers. 

Hydrogen is a fundamental element in the transition to low carbon (or hydrogen) economy and hydrogen generation will form a key part of the integrated infrastructure in the Centre. The hydrogen generated will be utilised as fuel for a polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell alongside other applications. Therefore, as part of the equipment portfolio, we are looking to procure a 30-35kW PEM fuel cell system. The PEM fuel cell system will support our extensive current and future research activities in low carbon energy generation, integrated energy systems and hydrogen economy.

Title: Evolution of Barriers to Gene Exchange
Description:
Previous work in the Butlin group within the University of Sheffield has produced a draft genome assembly for the focal species (the marine snail Littorina saxatilis) and re-sequencing has identified regions of the genome involved in adaptive differentiation between ecotypes. The current project aims to genotype a large sample of individuals for markers in these differentiated regions and in control regions in order to further understand the operation of natural selection in this system. 

This tender is funded by the ERC

Title: 2270/DM - Radio frequency Equipment
Description:
The Urban Flows Observatory at The University of Sheffield, led by the Departments of Civil and Structural and Automatic Control and Systems Engineering, is intending to undertake a survey of wireless networks using radio frequency technology. This will cover frequencies operated for Wi-Fi, Internet of Things (IoT) connectivity and cellular/mobile systems. 

The purpose is to provide measurements of signal strength, signal-noise ratio and coverage to assess the likelihood of interference and problems that may be encountered as new systems are implemented to support the proliferation of low-power sensing that will form part of the IoT. Research is also planned that will inform how rapid changes to the urban landscape affect both regulated and unlicensed network systems and consider what steps could be taken to plan for transmission/reception issues.

The Observatory is looking to purchase three distinct systems and could be based on different product offerings, possibly from differing manufacturers or suppliers. 

The systems required are:

1. Drive-test analyser
2. Walk-test analyser
3. Automated directional signal analyser (this could be combined with 1 in particular though the capability to use with 2 also would be seen as a benefit)

Title: Structural Engineer for Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC)
Description:
The University of Sheffield (UoS) will establish a national Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) at the (Advanced Manufacturing Research Campus) AMRC in the Innovation District. In line with both regional and national innovation priorities TERC will provide facilities to develop low carbon technologies as both individual processes and as part of integrated energy systems. This will be achieved by installing renewable energy generation, bio energy and smart grid equipment in, and bringing an enhanced Pilot-Scale Advanced CO2-Capture Technology facility to, a bespoke building.  The building will be circa 1,600sqm with 400sqm of covered external storage and 900sqm of external area for equipment plus associated car parking, service yard and landscaping.  Their will be circa 20-24 pieces of equipment.  The approximate value of the construction works is £4m for the base build plus £2m for the shell enhancement for the supply and connection of services to the research equipment.

Title: SQUID Magnetometer
Description:
We invite tenders to supply a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer. This will form a significant investment as part of the creation of the Sir Henry Royce Institute in Materials Discovery at the University of Sheffield. 

The SQUID magnetometer will characterize a wide range of materials, including ferromagnetic and ferrimagnetic bulk, thin film, patterned array and nanoparticle samples, materials for nuclear waste immobilization, electroceramics, multiferroics, novel alloys and materials for nuclear fusion technology. This breadth of sample type dictates the requirement for a flexible system with a unique range of capabilities and recirculating cryogens.
 
Delivery will be required between August & no later than the end of October 2018

It is currently a visitor instrument on the European Southern Observatory's (ESO) 3.5m New Technology Telescope (NTT) at La Silla, Chile. The instrument was built by a consortium involving the Universities of Sheffield, Warwick, and the UK Astronomy Technology Centre in Edinburgh. Title: Flow Cytometer with automatic plate loader
Description:
The University of Sheffield has awarded a tender on behalf of the Department of Animal and Plant Sciences for a Flow Cytometer with automatic plate loader. 

The system will support a wide range of applications, ranging from estimating microbial population dynamics to quantifying proportion of fluorescent protein marked bacterial strains in competition-based fitness assays. Importantly, the new flow cytometer will be equipped with automatic plate loader, to conduct high throughput assays by automatically measuring the performance of 96 populations at time.

Title: 1330/203/YE Environmental Chamber - AWARD
Description:
The University of Sheffield has awarded a tender on behalf of the Department of Mechanical Engineering for an Environmental Chamber 

The Laboratory for Verification and Validation (LVV) will be a new facility providing a unique capability for vibration and acoustic testing of substantial structures, sub-structures and components under environmentally realistic conditions. The environmental chamber within the LVV will be unique due to its size and versatility in environmental and vibrational experimental capabilities. The central component will be the large volume walk-in complex with the ability to control temperature (-55ºC to 50ºC), humidity (10-80%), wind (0-50 mph) and to simulate rain and, potentially, snow.  Facilities required in the Environmental Chamber include a a 3-axis hydraulic shake table with two further, mobile single-axis electrodynamic shakers being provided for use in any of the chambers; this will allow the full range of dynamic and acoustic testing planned for the chamber. All of the integrated vibration equipment will need to be properly protected against water ingress and extremes of temperature in order to be compatible with the chamber’s operation

This tender is being conducted under the EU Competitive procedure with Negotiation. The tender has now been awarded and no further expressions of interest will be accepted.

Title: 265/EML/PTG/15 Hybrid Machine Tool
Description:
The University of Sheffield invited tenders on behalf of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre`s Process Technology Group (PTG) at Catcliffe in Rotherham.

Scope:

The supply, installation and commissioning of a hybrid machine tool  for practical research into additive and  subtractive manufacture of complex components such as gears.  The equipment will be used to demonstrate novel and emerging methods of additive manufacture and ultrasonic assisted subtractive machining on a single platform and should have the flexibility to manufacture numerous sorts of component from the aerospace, automotive and other high value manufacturing industries; including gears, shafts, casings and housing, disks, blades, etc.  The equipment will also support the AMRC’s fundamental research into technologies such as machinability, dynamics and process monitoring, particularly with regard to the novel processes of additive manufacture and ultrasonic assisted subtractive manufacture.  As the equipment will be utilised for research projects rather than production, its usage will be subject to frequent change to suit different projects.  The solution should therefore be readily and rapidly changeable to enable work in a new mode of operation.

Title: CREST2 Project Materials Testing
Description:
262/EML/ASTC/15 CREST2 Project Materials Testing                                                                                           

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for supply to the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre at Catcliffe, Rotherham.

Scope of Requirement:

The intention is to create framework agreement for a number of services, described as lots. Each lot will be awarded to a single supplier.

The CREST2 project is a collaborative project between Airbus UK, Messier-Bugatti-Dowty, Carpenter Technologies and the University of Sheffield (UoS). The UoS is supplying the consortium with key tests data. The project objective is to remove the need for using non REACH compliant products in the manufacture of large structural aerospace components. 

The University of Sheffield, through its Advanced Structural Testing Centre (ASTC), will commission tests and control the conversion of the Carpenter Technologies material into test coupons and the delivery of test results.

All testing is required to be undertaken by organisations holding specific accreditation from Messier-Bugatti-Dowty for the provision of testing. 

The required Testing Services shall be undertaken off the AMRC facility and have been categorised as follows:

Lot 1	Tensile Testing to ASTM E8/E8M
Lot 2 	Compression testing to ASTM E9-09
Lot 3	Fracture toughness testing to ASTM E399-09
Lot 4	Shear Strength testing to ASTM B769-07
Lot 5	Grain size checks to ASTM E112-10
Lot 6 	Fatigue testing to PCS-7400 

It is anticipated that the time required to complete the project would be in the region of 24 months. A framework will be established for this initial period of 24 months commencing as soon as possible. This period may be extended no longer than 6 months post the initial contract term, if so required, to meet need and to complete project requirements.

Tender Process and Documentation:

This is an E.U open exercise. The ITT can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield.

If you have any questions or comments in relation to this tender they must be submitted via the In-tend System, this can be accessed at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield

Completed tenders must be returned through the same e-tendering system.

Closing date for receipt of tenders: 16th of July 2015 at 12 noon (UK time).
Additional Text:
Contract period is 24 months from award (option to extend for a further 6 months post initial term).
Value of the contract for the maximum period is in range between £50,000 - £170,000.

Title: Framework for Supply of Metallic Powders
Description:
258/SW/N/15 Framework for Supply of Metallic Powders                                                                                

The University of Sheffield wishes to invite tenders for supply to the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre at Catcliffe and to Faculty of Engineering at Sheffield.

Scope of Requirement:

The University of Sheffield wishes to establish a framework agreement with a number of Suppliers to enable requirements for metallic powders to be called off, for supply in the most economically advantageous manner. 

This requirement for metallic powder feed stocks arises from the technologies employed at both the Mercury Centre and AMRC; these processes currently include the following:
•	Additive Layer Manufacturing
•	Metal Injection Moulding (MIM)
•	Hot Isostatic Pressing (HIP)
•	Spark Plasma Sintering (SPS)
•	Diode Laser Cladding (DLC)

Framework will be for initial period from the 1st of August 2015 until the 31st of July 2016 with an option to extend annually, post review on each anniversary, until 31st of July 2018.

Title: 1387/MR Construction of three Industrial/Commercial Structures
Description:
Tender Opportunity 1387/MR - Pqq


All organisations with relevant experience are invited to tender.

This is the Pqq stage of a restricted procedure for construction services.

This is a project co-funded with European funds for the construction of three separate buildings.

The University wishes to establish the integrated Civil and Infrastructure Research Centre. The iCAIR will leverage the University's regional capacity in the Eight Great Technologies and Sector Strategies to foster and accelerate translational innovation in civil engineering, national infrastructure and advanced construction.

The building shall be constructed to satisfy B R E E A M 'Excellent' rating, current building regulations and achieve Secured by Design accreditation.

The University wishes to establish the Lvv as a national centre of excellence for structural dynamics research, with a particular focus on Validation and Verification (V&V) and Structural Health Monitoring (SHM).

The building shall be constructed to satisfy B R E E A M 'Excellent' rating, current building regulations and achieve Secured by Design accreditation.

The Royce Translational Centre will become a World leading facility for the science of materials processing, coupling the University's internationally renowned expertise in materials science and engineering with unique capability in manufacturing. The intention is to create an environment where academy, commerce and government can collaborate to address multi-disciplinary issues of materials processing, to co-create new knowledge and understanding which is rapidly exploited for commercial, environmental and humanitarian benefit.

The building shall be constructed to satisfy B R E E A M 'Excellent' rating, current building regulations and achieve Secured by Design accreditation.


Bidders can bid for one or more of these structures

Title: 1754/JN - Car Park Management Service for Solly Street Multi Storey Car Park
Description:
TUOS Parking Limited are seeking to appoint an operator to manage Solly Street car park in Sheffield. The operator will work to offer maximisation of profitability using an innovative model to achieve this.

The car park entrance is located on Solly Street as an under croft to part of the Velocity Village.  There are 560 spaces over 3 levels, but with the upper 2 levels stepped over a number of stages, the car park can be exited via White Croft or Solly Street.
The car park is barrier controlled 'Pay on Foot' with dual entry lanes and 2 exits. There is currently one cash and card pay machine located adjacent to the lodge on the White Croft exit. The car park operates using a Scheidt & Bachmann chip coin system. This is at the end of its serviceable life and in need of upgrading to improve customer experience and PCI compliance, and also to improve enhanced operating and reporting capability.

Title: 2259/JN - Core Loss Measurement Facility for Soft Magnetic Materials
Description:
The Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering has secured funding from the UK Enginerring and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) to establish the EPSRC Manufacturing Hub for Future Electrical Machines in partnership with the universities of Newcastle and Strathclyde. This funding includes provision to establish some key facilities in support of the research programme of the Hub. The specific facility being sought in this tender will provide a means of measuring hysteresis characteristics and AC core loss of soft magnetic material samples. It will be used almost entirely for the characterisation of laminated electrical steels (SiFe, CoFe and NiFe) for use in electrical machines and not high frequency cores for power supplies etc. Hence, medium frequency measurements of core loss (up to 1kHz) will cover the overwhelming majority of potential usage. It will be used almost exclusively for research purposes and not for offering commercial measuring services. A key use will be for evaluating the effect of electrical machine manufacturing methods on core loss.

Title: High Pressure CO2 Coolant System with Minimum Quantity Lubrication Ability
Description:
1986/382/CW/AMRC/18 High Pressure CO2 Coolant System with Minimum Quantity Lubrication Ability 

The AMRC requires delivery, installation, testing and commissioning of a system to provide high pressure CO2 and MQL coolant to an existing machine, with the outcome of reducing tool wear and/or allowing for more aggressive/faster cuts.

The system should be externally connected and should be supplied with its own base. The system should allow the machine to alternate between traditional emulsion through tool coolant and through tool supply of CO2 with minimum intervention.

The Cooling System shall be fitted onto a Cincinnati H5-800MT Geminex 5-Axis which is currently undergoing an upgrade at the AMRC's nominated supplier, Machine Tool Technologies Limited ( MTT ) -at the address below:
MACHINE TOOL TECHNOLOGIES LIMITED
SUITE 1H RIBBLE COURT
1 MEAD WAY
BURNLEY
BB12 7NG

It is desired that the coolant system will be fitted during the upgrade at MTT's premises. 

The successful Tenderer will be required to co-ordinate with MTT and all other interested stakeholders to ensure that all necessary arrangements are established for completion of the project in the following phases:

Phase One: 
Delivery, installation and commissioning of the coolant system fitted to the Cincinnati H5-800MT Geminex 5-Axis.
On completion of commissioning, testing to be conducted to confirm the system is operating correctly. 
Final acceptance by University.

Phase Two:
On final acceptance, the Tenderer shall decommission the equipment, any Rotary Union etc shall remain in place within the Cincinnati machine.
The Tenderer to remove and store at own premises and cost, pending re-commissioning at Phase Three of the project.

Phase Three:
In collaboration with MTT and the Purchase, co-ordinate the delivery of the coolant system at the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre
Delivery, Installation, Testing, Re-Commissioning at the Advanced Manufacturing Research Park, Catcliffe, Rotherham.

Final Acceptance by the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre

The price submitted should take into account all costs incurred for full turnkey provision, at all at all phases of the project and shall include any transportation and storage costs that may be incurred.

Title: 2053/JN - High Resolution Field Emission Electron Probe Microanalyser (FE-EPMA)
Description:
The Sheffield Royce Institute is a~£34M project based in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering. Sheffield is part of the national Henry Royce Institute (with the main Hub in Manchester) which aims to grow the UK world-leading research and innovation base in advanced materials science, fundamental to all industrial sectors and the national economy. The Sheffield Royce Institute focuses on Advanced Materials Processing and will be delivered through two centres - the Royce Discovery Centre (RDC) and the Royce Translational Centre (RTC). These state of the art facilities will allow materials discovery, materials manufacturing and prototype production and will act as an open access centre of excellence for the UK. 

We seek to purchase a state of the art, computer-controlled user friendly, Field Emission Electron Probe Microanalyser (FE-EPMA). The instrument will be used for spatially resolved, quantitative, determination of material composition of a wide range of different materials. The EPMA should have both WDS and EDS.

Title: 2464/JN - Instrumentation for Label-free Biomolecule Interaction Analysis
Description:
With co-funding from NIHR (National Institute for Health Research) we seek equipment offering reliable, user-friendly, quantitative, label-free determination of molecular interactions between a wide variety of biomolecules.

We focus on the problems of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) from fundamental science to translation into clinical benefit. We bring together scientists and clinicians to tackle all aspects of AMR. One aspect of our work relates to understanding the molecular mechanisms of AMR. The ability to measure molecular interactions in a quantitative manner will enhance our research capabilities. The ability to measure the strength of interactions is crucial to mechanistic understanding, e.g. between a bacterial protein and an antibiotic.

Our current equipment is a single channel, operator-intensive machine that is suitable for preliminary studies on molecules with a molecular weight of > 10,000 Da. This has become a bottleneck for our studies due to: 1) its low capacity and 2) its inability to detect interactions between small molecules has prompted us to acquire extra capabilities and increased throughput.

Scope of Requirement
      The AMRC North West has a requirement to engage with local industries in the region and provide solutions to manufacturing challenges. As part of that remit, there is a need to purchase a CMM to support the manufacturing projects.

Title: 2196/JS - Laser Scanning Microscope and High Content Microscope (2 Lots)
Description:
The newly founded Weston Park Cancer Centre requires a new laser scanning confocal microscope and a new high content microscope to support its research in basic and translational cancer research. The confocal microscope will be used for high resolution imaging of fixed and live cells including techniques such as FRET, FRAP and laser microirradiation. High sensitivity, image quality and usability are of great importance. The high content microscope will be used for high throughput imaging of fixed and live cells for various pre-clinical and clinical screening purposes. Samples imaged on both systems will mostly be cell monolayers but can also be tissue sections and spheroids.

This tender is broken into 2 Lots:-
Lot 1 - Laser Scanning Microscope
Lot 2 - High Content Microscope

Title: 2052/JN - High Resolution Field Emission Gun Scanning Electron Microscope
Description:
The Sheffield Royce Institute is a~£34M project based in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering. Sheffield is part of the national Henry Royce Institute (with the main Hub in Manchester) which aims to grow the UK world-leading research and innovation base in advanced materials science, fundamental to all industrial sectors and the national economy. The Sheffield Royce Institute focuses on Advanced Materials Processing and will be delivered through two centres - the Royce Discovery Centre (RDC) and the Royce Translational Centre (RTC). These state of the art facilities will allow materials discovery, materials manufacturing and prototype production and will act as an open access centre of excellence for the UK.

We seek to purchase a state of the art, computer-controlled user friendly, Field Emission Gun Scanning Electron Microscope. The instrument will be used for the high resolution imaging of a wide range of materials, but with a particular focus on metals.  The FEGSEM should have EDS and EBSD capability and will be used for high-resolution studies of deformed metal structures.

Title: 1339/MH Data Visualisation Tool
Description:
We are looking to purchase a data visualisation tool and associated consultancy for the necessary implementation and training etc. 

Work is currently taking place to develop and improve the CDM to hold a greater range and more relevant data for reporting, MI and BI purposes; the University requires a modern and flexible data visualisation tool which will allow user friendly, high quality, interactive dashboards and other data visualisations to be developed and disseminated through a single portal, to capitalise on the improved data source. Reports and dashboards developed with the tool should be interactive and capable of drawing together data from across areas of operations to deliver a range of insight and encourage evidence-based decision making across the University.

Dashboards and visualisations will generally draw data from the CDM, but the system should also be capable of blending data from various sources if necessary. It should also be possible for data to be worked on within the system e.g. to perform grouping and calculations without using separate software e.g. exporting to Excel and re-importing.

Title: Viscometer
Description:
The Immobilisation Science Laboratory (ISL) is a world-leading centre for nuclear materials and nuclear waste immobilisation research. The ISL provides access to world-class expertise and facilities, thus enabling top-rate research in nuclear waste materials development and durability testing.

The Viscometer should be capable of evaluating the absolute viscosity of materials as a function of temperature, from ambient to 1500 deg C. It is important to understand the context that this equipment will be utilised, where appropriate, for analysis of radioactive materials (generally incorporating U or Th).

Title: 2393/DM - Fischer- Tropsch Plant
Description:
We are setting up a National Translational Energy Research Centre (TERC) and are looking to procure a wide range of new equipment focusing on bio-energy, renewable energy and carbon capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS) technologies. Flue gas from all combustion systems will be integrated into the on-site carbon capture plants. The captured C02 will be utilised in an on-site Fischer-Tropsch plant along with hydrogen generated onsite from renewable resources in order to produce green fuel for use in the turbines/engines for full-chain CCUS demonstration. As part of the equipment portfolio we are looking to procure a Fischer-Tropsch plant for aviation fuel production to broaden and support our extensive research, development and deployment activities at the
centre. The plant will take C02 and H2 from storage and convert it to aviation liquid fuels.

Title: 5 Axis Milling Machine Purchase
Description:
This tender is for the supply, installation and commissioning of a 5-axis milling machine for use in research machining studies. The equipment will be used for testing and demonstration purposes in the AMRC North West's interim facility in Preston and ultimately in a new facility at Samlesbury. 
The equipment will support the AMRC's research into technologies such as machinability, dynamics and process monitoring. The equipment should have adequate robustness, high precision and repeatability to facilitate the manufacture of high performance aerospace, automotive and similar parts with demanding tolerance requirements.  As the equipment will be utilised for research projects rather than production, its usage will be subject to frequent change to suit different projects.  The solution should therefore be readily and rapidly changeable to work in new modes of operation.

Compulsory requirements: 
 
1.	Must have the ability to machine a range of aerospace, automotive and other high value manufacturing industries; including titanium, nickel superalloys, steel and stainless steel.
2.	Machine including ancillaries must not exceed 3000mm (length) x 3000mm (width) and 3000mm (height) see attached Diagram 1 for more detail. 
3.	Must weigh a maximum 10,000Kg or less.
4.	Must have a tool magazine with a capacity of at least 25 tools.
5.	Must include Sprint Probe.
6.	Must have a minimum spindle speed of 18,000RPM.
7.	Must allow machining with 20 bar pressure coolant, through   tool coolant and flood.
8.	Must have a working envelope (diameter x height) no less than 400 x 400 mm for all modes of operation.

Title: Digital Image Correlation System
Description:
This measurement system is to support experimental measurements of dynamic pipe cracking. The DIC system will need to be capable of operating at a remote distance from the pipe test piece. 

It is expected that the measurement equipment will be between 1.0 and 2.0 m from the test piece.  The pipe test pieces will be manufactured from a range of common pipe materials, e.g. various plastics and cast iron. It will be possible to paint a speckle pattern on all these materials. The diameters will range from 50 to 300 mm. The size of the cracks and defects will range from the sub-millimetre to the tens of millimetres in size.

Title: 2015/PB - Hicks Building - New Substation
Description:
	Concourse substation main LV switchboard works (including high voltage switching).
	Fit out works to proposed Edwardian LV switch room (former external gas store) to include small power, lighting, emergency lighting and fire detection.
	All builders work associated with the above works to include structural remedial work to proposed Edwardian switch room roof, enabling works to provide safe access for routing of high level external power cables and temporary works to provide protection to existing equipment fixtures and fittings.
	Edwardian Building Switchboard Installation to include the supply, installation, testing and commissioning of the switchboard, metering installation and the transfer of all outgoing ways from the existing panel boards/main switch board to the new switchboard.
	Supply installation, testing and commissioning of a generator connection to Level G Alfred Denny plant room and the installation of a new section board to the Level G Animal Sciences laboratory area. 
	Alfred Denny LV Switchboard installation to include the supply installation, testing and commissioning of the switchboard, fit out of the room, metering installation, cable jointing and transferal of all outgoing ways from existing panel to new switchboard.
	Winter Street Substation LV Switchboard alterations to include the installation of additional electrical "cabinets" to extend main low voltage switchboard, high voltage switching and Isolation of high voltage and low voltage cabling where required.
	Transformer inspection and maintenance to include the IUS limited inspection and maintenance works to both transformers.
	The limits of the site boundary are detailed upon drawing (01)001.
During the Construction Phase, the adacent Hicks and Student Union buildings will be fully occupied during normal working hours (8am - 6pm Monday to Friday). Access restrictions for all of the working areas will be in place throughout the contract and are indicated on the proposed limitations (11) series drawings. Works will be undertaken both within live occupied spaces and out of hours during which the rooms will be vacant. Careful consideration must be given to providing a means of segregating the works from the building occupants.

The project is to be delivered in a single phase, with the works comencing on the ** ** ** and the completion date being the ** ** **. Works are to be delivered on a five day working pattern with out of hours working required throughout the contract period. Title: Summative Assessments (3 reports)
Description:
We are looking for a consultant or organisation to carry out three individual Summative Assessments to satisfy ERDF compliance to be completed by the end of June 2018 (this specifically applies to two of the projects & further information is provided within the tender specification).

The Summative Assessments, required by our funders should be underpinned by a programme of active and planned engagement with project beneficiaries and the project team. This will culminate in a final evaluation on conclusion of the project which will focus on assessing overall impact and lessons learned which might inform the design of future projects.

A summative assessment is a specific requirement of our funders and must be completed by the end of June 2018. It will be impact based and undertaken according to the funder's common framework and methodology, a link to which is included in the tender specification.

Title: Nanoindenter for a Scanning Electron Microscope
Description:
The equipment we are looking for should enable the mechanical testing of materials within a scanning electron microscope (SEM) via insertion of a vacuum compatible mechanical testing holder/stage. 

The mechanical testing device should have mechanisms for enabling both Nanoindentation and Scratch testing methodologies, under specified loading conditions, together with in-situ measurement of applied load and position. The mechanical testing device should be transferable between the air and microscope column, be compatible with the high vacuum of the SEM, and fit within specified microscope geometries.

Title: Hard X-Ray Diffractometer
Description:
We require a new High performance X-ray Diffractometer using hard (Ag and Mo) radiation for our advanced characterisation facility.
This diffractometer must be capable of rapid data collection from the wide diversity of materials studied by TUoS researchers - both small bulk pieces (pellets, off-cuts etc.) and powdered specimens of ceramics, cements and refractories, metals and glasses. We then require the ability to perform a range of additional specialised techniques on powdered specimens:

PDF analyses, and in situ / operando experiments using high pressure, low temperature or electrochemical coin
and/or pouch cells during charge/discharge.

The AF4 system together with UV/Vis and RI detector must be capable of separating and quantifying species with a wide range of molecular weights, as well as being able to do this at low concentrations and with the minimum disruption to the concentration of the injected sample to maintain a similar distribution of aggregates during the analysis. Title: Industrial Biotechnology Landscape Report Provision
Description:
BBSRC, with support from EPSRC, have committed £18M to fund 13 unique collaborative Networks in Industrial Biotechnology and Bioenergy (BBSRC NIBB). The BBSRC NIBB foster collaborations between academia, industry, policy makers and NGOs in order to find new approaches to tackle research challenges, translate research and deliver key benefits in Industrial Biotechnology (IB). Each network has a particular focus area, mainly within the UK, but with interest to build international links.  These multidisciplinary networks will drive new ideas to harness the potential of biological resources for producing and processing materials, biopharmaceuticals, chemicals and energy.

Four NIBB; BIOCATNET, C1Net, CBMNet, and P2P, are commissioning this project with the aim of mapping the strengths of the entire UK Industrial Biotechnology sector.  The focus of the project should be on research and development through to commercialisation with additional focus on Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 4-7. The target audience for the report are UK funders and The Government.

These devices will be located at our new, purpose built AMRC Wales facility based at Broughton, Flintshire. The facility will open in October 2019.

There are 5 lots available.

LOT 1: Serial Arm Robot with >200kg payload 

LOT 2: Serial Arm Robot with >700kg payload 

LOT 3: Serial Arm Robot Training Cell 

LOT 4: Serial arm robot with >7kg payload for use within high care food manufacturing environment

LOT 5: 4 axis SCARA robot for use within high care food manufacturing environment

The Invitation to tender with the specification and associated tendering instructions can be downloaded by registering and expressing your interest on the University`s e-tendering system https://in-tendhost.co.uk/Sheffield.

If you have any questions or comments in relation to this tender they must be submitted via the In-tend system. Submissions must be uploaded to the portal before the submission deadline.

Title: Live Cell Imaging System
Description:
Supply, installation and commissioning of Live Cell Imaging System, for undergraduate teaching activities in the University's new flagship Diamond Building, due to open in September 2015. Warranty and service contracts for 3 or more years is required.

We require a device to monitor living cells in culture and quantitatively measure multiple parameters of their physical activity and biochemical activity over time.  The device must provide the correct environmental conditions to maintain human and animal cells or cells lines in monolayer culture viable by means of temperature, humidity and atmospheric control.  We require both light microscopy and fluorescence microscopy of multiple regions of interest recorded over time in multiple cultures with data recorded by computer and made available in readily accessible formats.

Title: 5 Axis Milling Machine Purchase
Description:
This tender is for the supply, installation and commissioning of a 5-axis milling machine for use in research machining studies. The equipment will be used for testing and demonstration purposes in the AMRC North West's interim facility in Preston and ultimately in a new facility at Samlesbury. 

The equipment will support the AMRC's research into technologies such as machinability, dynamics and process monitoring. The equipment should have adequate robustness, high precision and repeatability to facilitate the manufacture of high performance aerospace, automotive and similar parts with demanding tolerance requirements.  As the equipment will be utilised for research projects rather than production, its usage will be subject to frequent change to suit different projects.  The solution should therefore be readily and rapidly changeable to work in new modes of operation.

Title: GB-Bristol: SBRI Challenge - Fuel and Lubricants
Description:
The work is to be undertaken in accordance with the SBRI application 59597-444192 part 8 submitted to and held by Innovate UK for the Fuels and Lubricants programme.
Conduct a study and develop a model to enable evaluation of the effect of varying level and type of aromatics in conventional and synthetic fuel blends on system compatibility, fuel system life and soot/particulate production impact on hot-end life, signature and emissions.
The key deliverables of the project are as follows:
1. Investigate a selection of aromatic species and blends of blends for elastomer compatibility and particulate/smoke emissions from combustion devices.
2. Investigate blends for particulate/smoke emissions and heat signature from a range of combustion devices
3. Investigate correlations between elastomer swell, particulate emissions, smoke and aromatic species.
4. Develop a model to predict smoke, particulate emissions and seal swell.
5. Deliver Phase 1 Final Report and preliminary assessment model

Title: Stage 3 SBRI Nano-steels project extension
Description:
Phase 3 of the project 'Nano-Structured Steels to Extend Operational Performance for Nuclear Reactors' will serve as a direct continuation to the  previous  Phases  of  the  project  and  will principally investigate the potential viability of the experimental steel alloys for use as structural materials  in  nuclear  reactors  that  could  operate  at  higher  temperatures  and/or  in  different reactor designs. This is planned by investigating the microstructures and testing mechanical properties  of  the  alloys  to  provide  indicative  information  for  whether  the  material  is  likely suitable as a high temperature structural material in a nuclear environment. The alloys in question are alloys 666 and 694.
Both alloys will be investigated in the heat-treated and tempered condition. Alloy 694 is already in this condition. Alloy 666 will receive this treatment at the start of this proposed project on the as-forged 666 bar produced in Phase 2.

Title: ELM Social Research
Description:
The government is committed to involving a wide range of stakeholders in every stage of the process of designing the Environmental Land Management System (ELMS) to ensure that we form an agricultural policy which benefits British farmers, the environment, consumers, taxpayers and the wider rural community.  We are, therefore, urgently seeking valuable subject-specific social science expertise to our evidence base and provide access to the most current co-design approaches to inform our programme of work.

The social science team within the ELM Programme aims to support agri-environment policy development and respond to the Secretary of State's requirement for the next generation of agri-environment instruments to be simple, "provide flexibility, putting more management decisions in the hands of farmers" and "deliver more for the environment" .

The provision of expert social science input must be delivered by a contractor with advanced qualifications in a relevant social science discipline; extensive experience of conducting research relating to farmer decision-making and stakeholder engagement in an agricultural context; and providing research findings relevant to and in collaboration with a government department.  The contractor will follow the Government Social Research (GSR) Professional Guidance on ethical research conduct; meet the quality requirements outlined by the GSR; and have a clear protocol for collecting and storing data.
Additional Text: Please note that Defra procurement uses an E-tendering system for Procurement activities.  This is currently provided by Bravo Solutions.   To access appropriate tendering and contractual documents, please access the E-Tendering portal at https://defra.bravosolution.co.uk", ensuring that your registration includes "Defra".  If you have any problems with this system, please contact Bravo on their telephone helpline number 0800 368 4850 or by emailing them at help@bravosolution.co.uk. "

Title: UK SBS RE160487 WEC#4 Operations Support
Description:
The final date and time for submission has been extended to Monday 6th of February 2017 at 14:00

DO NOT apply directly to the buyer.

All tender information MUST be submitted through the CCS eSourcing Portal.

Brief Description of Requirement

The overall context of this tender is the ongoing ESA four-satellite Cluster mission which was successfully launched in July and August 2000. Each Cluster spacecraft contains a complete suite of eleven instruments to measure magnetic and electric fields, electromagnetic waves, and particles. The Cluster nominal mission phase started on 1 February 2001. Planned to last for 2 years, it has been extended numerous times and on 22 November 2016 ESA's Science Programme Committee (SPC) approved a further two year extension to the end of 2018 with an option on a further extension up to end 2020 (TBC by the ESA SPC meeting in
February or June 2017).
From the beginning, a critical part of the Cluster Science Ground Segment has been the Joint Science Operations Centre (JSOC) located at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, a facility operated by the UK's Science and Technology Facilities Council (STFC). In addition to JSOC carrying out its baseline operational activities ESA has now requested, starting in early 2017, that JSOC also carries out specific Operations Support for four of the five WEC instruments (DWP, EFW, STAFF and WHISPER - referred to WEC#4 for clarity) on each of the four Cluster Satellites. However, STFC does not possess the in-house expertise, or systems, to be able to carry out WEC#4 Operations Support and will therefore subcontract this work out.
The specific context, and purpose, of this tender is to seek specific operational support for the WEC#4 instruments on each satellite, the details of which are given in the Statement of Work for WEC#4 Operations Support, document Appendix A DS-JSOC-SoW-0002. Further details of the Cluster mission, the WEC#4 instrument and its operation are given in the list of Appendix B

Please ensure you review all attached information to ensure a full understanding of this requirement. All attachments can be found with the RFx attachments tab within the Emptoris System. 

This contract will be awarded based on the evaluation criteria set out in the ITQ document.

Responses must be received by the date in the bid documents.

Responses received outside or concurrently using the eSourcing process will not be accepted or considered further for this opportunity.

How to Register on the CCS eSourcing Suite

Full details of this opportunity can be found on the e-sourcing portal please follow instructions below. If you have not yet registered on the eSourcing Suite, this can be done online at https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk by following the link 'Register for CCS eSourcing'. 

Please note that, to register, you must have a valid DUNS number (as provided by Dun and Bradstreet) for the organisation which you are registering, who will be entering into a contract if invited to do so. 

Once you have registered on the eSourcing Suite, a registered user can express an interest for a specific procurement. This is done by emailing expressionofinterest@crowncommercial.gov.uk. 

Your email must clearly state: 
•	name and reference for the procurement you wish to register for; 
•	name of the registered Bidder; 
•	name and contact details for the registered individual sending the email. 

Crown Commercial Service will process the email and then enable the Bidder to access the procurement online via the e-Sourcing Suite. The registered user will receive a notification email to alert them once this has been done. The Sourcing documents can then be accessed on the eSourcing Suite at: https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk using the instructions detailed in the Specification documents within Contracts Finder. 

As a user of the e-Sourcing Suite you will have access to Emptoris email messaging service which facilitates all messages sent to you and from you in relation to any specific RFX event. 

Please note it is your responsibility to access these emails on a regular basis to ensure you have sight of all relevant information. 

For technical assistance on use of the e-Sourcing Suite please contact Crown Commercial Service Helpdesk: Telephone: 0345 010 3503 

Training documents to support Bidders to utilise Emptoris CCS eSourcing are available in the Contracts Finder Tender documents section.

Our broad range of expert services is shared by our customers. This allows our customers the freedom to focus resources on core activities; innovating and transforming their own organisations.

Title: Children and Young People Education Mental Health Practitioner Programme, Health Education England- NHS/SoEPS/19.497
Description:
NHS South of England Procurement Services (SoEPS), acting on behalf of Health Education England (the Authority) are commencing a tender for the provision of a Children and Young People Education Mental Health Practitioner Programme.
Health Education England (HEE), in partnership with NHS England by 2020/21, commit to a significant expansion in access to high-quality mental health care for children and young people, with at least 70,000 additional children and young people each year receiving evidence-based treatment.

As part of the initiatives to support expansion there is a commitment to create a network of support for children and young people, and their educational settings (DHSC 2017). This includes establishing Mental Health Support Teams who will have the responsibility for delivering schools' overarching approach to providing mental health and wellbeing support for children and young people from January 2019. As part of the Mental Health Support Teams a new role called the Education Mental Health Practitioner (EMHP) is being established.

The implementation of the EMHP role will be underpinned by practitioners undertaking an accredited post graduate/graduate certificate programme of education and supervision in clinical practice. On successful completion of the programme, the learner will be equipped with the necessary skills, knowledge and capabilities to work as a qualified EMHP providing early intervention support for children and young people with mild to moderate mental health problems, and signposting to NHS and other appropriate services for further support.

This provision will split over 6 Geographic Lots.

The maximum value of this programme is £15,120,000 inclusive of any applicable VAT over a three year period across all 6 Lots.  The Authority reserves the right to extend the contracts by up to a further two years, to be determined on a Lot basis.

The first year of the programme will be up to £2,520,000 across all 6 Lots (£420,000 each Lot for tuition and supervision).

The funding is set at tuition costs of £11,500, inclusive of any applicable VAT, per learner in respect of the delivery of a postgraduate/graduate certificate completing the programme over a maximum period of 12 months.  The amount of £5,000, inclusive of any applicable VAT, will be available for training each Supervisor, with the expectation that supervisors can support up to two EMHP Trainees (1:2 Supervision trainer ratio). However, this may be adjusted for future cohorts as the training numbers increase.

Bidders are invited to access the procurement documentation at https://in-tendhost.co.uk/soepscommissioning
Please access the ITT procurement documents for further information.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and the Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West
Attachments: Instructions for Registering on the SoEPS Commissioning Support In-tend Portal.pdf
Additional Text:
The deadline for submission of completed ITT submissions is Friday 26 April 2019 at 12:00pm (midday).  Late submissions will not be accepted.  The e-portal system will shutdown at 12:00pm and any un-submitted bids not registered to the system at this time will not be accepted.  Therefore, please submit in good time prior to the deadline date and time.

Project title: Children and Young People Education Mental Health Practitioner Programme, Health Education England - NHS/SoEPS/19.497, please access the ITT for all documents.  Should Bidders have any queries regarding registration or are having problems using the portal, they should contact the In-tend dedicated Supplier Helpdesk by calling 0845 557 8079 Monday to Friday (9am to 5pm) or email support@in-tend.co.uk

All communications should be made via the messaging function on the In-tend E-Tendering portal.  During the tender exercise the Contracting Authority requests that all communications are channelled through the e-portal system via the appointed procurement specialist on behalf of NHS South of England Procurement Services and not with the Contracting Authority itself. No Bidder, Bidder Member, or any of such Bidder's advisors, consultants or subcontractors may have ex parte communications with the Contracting Authority or any of their employees, advisors, contractors or consultants regarding the ITT, the Procurement, other than as expressly permitted in this ITT.

Title: UK SBS CR19019 - LPC Open Call for Research on the Impact of the National Living Wage on Businesses
Description:
The final date and time for the submission of bids is Monday 18th March 2019 at 11:00

DO NOT apply directly to the buyer.

All tender information MUST be submitted through the CCS eSourcing Portal.

Brief Description of Requirement

The aim of this study is to gain a better understanding of the impact of minimum wages, especially the National Living Wage, on businesses. Up to three separate projects will be commissioned in this process.  The findings will inform LPC deliberations in October 2019 for the uprating of the NLW (and the other age-related minimum wage rates) in April 2020 and subsequent discussions for minimum wage changes beyond 2020.  This research will contribute to the understanding of how firms are adjusting to the NLW.
Please ensure you review all attached information to ensure a full understanding of this requirement. All attachments can be found with the RFx attachments tab within the Emptoris System.

Title: STEP WP11 - Feasibility Study of Modular Reactor Designs
Description:
This procurement is to gain knowledge on modular construction and Small Modular Reactor's and apply the learnings to the future STEP programme.   

To realise the STEP ambition, UKAEA wishes to appoint a Consultant(s) to deliver a study on the modular construction. Modular construction with manufactured components is being increasingly used in residential builds to help bring down costs (~30%) and speed up construction times. This "design for manufacture & assembly" construction approach needs to be considered from the design stage in order to fully benefit from this process. Small Modular Reactor (SMR) and Advanced Modular Reactors (AMR) designers are using a modular approach for nuclear reactors. This work will conduct a feasibility study to enable UKAEA to work with industry to gain knowledge and experience on how modular construction and Advanced Nuclear Technologies (SMRs or AMRs) design experience can be applied to STEP. Additionally, we wish the supplier to conduct a study on how Advanced Nuclear Technologies balance of plant design can be applied to STEP.

Title: GB-Bristol: SBRI Challenge - Fuel and Lubricants
Description:
The work is to undertaken in accordance with the SBRI application 59574-444188 part 8 submitted to and held by Innovate UK for the Fuels and Lubricants programme.
Investigate the interactions of conventional and synthetic fuel composition on combustion vibration, acoustic signature and consequent hot-end stress/life.

The key deliverables of the project are as follows:

1. Investigate the interactions of vibration, combustion instability, and noise when burning fuels at a range of equivalence ratios on a small combustor and single can RR spey combustor.
2. Investigate the interaction of vibration, combustion instability, noise and emissions when burning alternative and baseline fuels at a range of equivalence ratios on a small gas turbine (APU) platform
3.Develop models quantifying the effect of alternative fuel composition on combustor vibration, noise and combustion instability.

Title: SBRI Challenge - Fuels and Lubricants
Description:
The work is to be undertaken in accordance with the SBRI application 59597-444192 part 8 submitted to and held by Innovate UK for the Fuels and Lubricants programme.
Conduct a study and develop a model to enable evaluation of the effect of varying level and type of aromatics in conventional and synthetic fuel blends on system compatibility, fuel system life and soot/particulate production impact on hot-end life, signature and emissions.
The key deliverables of the project are as follows:
1. Investigate a selection of aromatic species and blends of blends for elastomer compatibility and particulate/smoke emissions from combustion devices.
2. Investigate blends for particulate/smoke emissions and heat signature from a range of combustion devices
3. Investigate correlations between elastomer swell, particulate emissions, smoke and aromatic species.
4. Develop a model to predict smoke, particulate emissions and seal swell.
5. Deliver Phase 1 Final Report and preliminary assessment model.

Title: SBRI CHALLENGE - FUELS and LUBRICANTS
Description:
The work is to undertaken in accordance with the SBRI application 59574-444188 part 8 submitted to and held by Innovate UK for the Fuels and Lubricants programme.
Investigate the interactions of conventional and synthetic fuel composition on combustion vibration, acoustic signature and consequent hot-end stress/life.

The key deliverables of the project are as follows:

1.  Investigate the interactions of vibration, combustion instability,  and noise when burning fuels at a range of equivalence ratios on a small combustor and single can RR spey combustor.
2. Investigate the interaction of vibration, combustion instability, noise and emissions when burning alternative and baseline fuels at a range of equivalence ratios on a small gas turbine (APU) platform
3.Develop models quantifying the effect of alternative fuel composition on combustor vibration, noise and combustion instability.

Title: SBRI Challenge-Enhanced Individual Protective Equipment
Description:
This project will employ Additive Manufacturing (3D Printing) techniques in order to produce personalised protective body armour solutions with minimum impact on the wearers performance.
Additive Manufacturing processes build parts layer-by-layer, directly from a 3D Computer-Aided Design (CAD) model, and differs from conventional manufacturing techniques as it requires no tooling. This facilitates the realisation of design concepts that are typically too expensive, difficult or impossible to create using traditional manufacturing processes, including complex internal geometries and multiple assemblies as a single unit. The work is to be undertaken in accordance with the SBRI application 58420-443195 part 8, as submitted to and held by Innovate UK for the Enhanced Individual Protective Equipment Protection  programme.

Title: NU/1246-17 Rail Infastructure Investigation: Commercialisation of university research through provision of management skills to assist in successful spin-out company creation.
Description:
Rail Infrastructure Investigation Limited  (RIIL) is a proposed spinout from Durham's Department of Earth Sciences,The University of Sheffield's Department of Physics and St Mary's University, Twickenham, Department of Physics.  It intends to conduct surveys of Victorian rail infrastructure and a Chief Executive Officer (CEO) is required to take full responsibility for all commercial aspects from "pre-spin-out" to fully-fledged company with revenues in the region £10m -£30m.

RIIL will utilise novel IP and know-how from three universities; (Durham, Sheffield and Saint Mary's London), and a well-established Rail contractor.   It will help Network Rail Ltd to more efficiently maintain their portfolio of 332 Victorian railway tunnels and 171 Victorian brick built viaducts.  Current inspection methods require physically drilling into the structure to discover unseen "voids".   RIIL will offer a non-destructive alternative to this inspection method.  The equipment and methods are new to the rail environment.
The first market for RIIL services is intended to be the UK Rail network.  Additional markets such as mining, mine remediation and utilities (sewage and water) also exist.  Additionally, if resolution can be improved, complicated structures, such as older buildings, could be surveyed for damage or faults.  This potential market is currently not completely understood and addressing this will be a key task of the CEO. 

Sheffield, Durham and St Mary's University are currently collaborating in a joint research to develop a next generation, high TRL level instrument in Sheffield.  This work will continue in parallel to the Northern Accelerator work and the CEO will be expected to collaborate with it in order to maximise the benefits to the future spinout company.
